subject: Training Industry Weekly Recap 📅 July 30, 2023
body:
Fall virtual TICE, AI Leader Talk and more.
View this email in your browser
THE BUSINESS OF LEARNING™
Employees continue to prioritize growth in their career journeys so, naturally, they want to work for organizations that invest in their growth and development. This is why learning and development (L&D) is essential to organizational success!
To support you in this essential role, we’re 
featuring articles
 that offer insights into how L&D can have the biggest impact on the business, how to measure that impact and how to convey that impact to stakeholders.
We also have some great opportunities for you to come together with other learning leaders and learn from some of the best in the industry at our fall virtual 
Training Industry Conference & Expo (TICE)
 and our upcoming Leader Talk about making the most of artificial intelligence (AI) in your learning tech stack.
We hope these resources will help make it easier for you to confidently establish yourself as a trusted business partner. Please send any comments or suggestions to 
editor@trainingindustry.com
.
Jenny Ayers
Associate Editor
Register Now: 2023 Fall Virtual TICE
Get ready to unlock the secrets to building a powerful learning strategy! You’re invited to the virtual 
Training Industry Conference and Expo (TICE)
 Sept. 27-28 where we are focusing on building your learning strategy. Join us online from anywhere in the world and connect with over 1000 of your L&D peers! This conference is specifically designed to equip you with the skills and knowledge needed to drive impact and maximize the return on investment (ROI) of your L&D initiatives.
Learn More
 
Leader Talk: Managing Learning Technologies in the Age of AI
Learning leaders are increasingly expected to double as technology experts as learning technologies continue to emerge and evolve at a rapid pace. When you factor in the additional element of AI within these tools, it can be very difficult to know what’s the best fit for your training needs. Join us for this complimentary 
Leader Talk
 on Aug. 10 to get tips from industry experts on how to leverage and manage AI tools to support your L&D efforts.
Reserve Your Spot
 
Training Needs Assessment, Simplified
Great training starts with a robust needs assessment that highlights skills gaps and identifies learning opportunities that can help fill them. However, creating a comprehensive needs assessment isn’t easy. That’s why we’ve created a free, step-by-step checklist to assist you alongside your needs assessment journey. Download the checklist today and learn more about how Training Industry’s 
Training Needs Assessment Certificate
 can help you master the needs assessment process to take your training from good to great.

subject: Are you collaborating the right way?
body:
Apply research-based principles to unlock better collaboration. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
BOOKS
 
 
 
 
COLLECTIONS
 
 
 
 
TOOLS
 
 
 
 
CASE STUDIES
 
 
 
HBR STORE
 
 
 
 
 
Achieve more with smarter collaboration 
 
Today’s business problems are increasingly complex, and so are the solutions. With HBR’s 
Smarter Collaboration Diagnostic Toolkit
, you get an action plan to embed more effective collaboration within your organization and maximize success. 
 
 
 
 
 
LEARN HOW TO:
•
Collect diagnostic data via surveys, interviews, and focus groups
•
Analyze how well you’re currently collaborating
•
Communicate and disseminate your findings
•
Ready your team to become stronger collaborators
•
Embed smarter collaboration to boost innovation
•
And much more
 
LEARN MORE
 
 
 
 
 
 
THE EBOOK
Firms that collaborate effectively consistently generate higher revenues and profit. 
Smarter Collaboration
 lays out a pragmatic action plan with practical advice to help companies collaborate in a smarter way. 
 
 
5 MODULES
From conducting qualitative research to making transformative changes, these modules provide the essential guidance and tools needed to transform your organization. 
 
 
6 VIDEOS
Each short video provides further insight on how to diagnose collaboration across your organization. 
 
 
9 WORKSHEETS
As you roll out research findings, use these worksheets to empower your people to incorporate better collaboration into their day-to-day work. 
 
 
THE HANDBOOK
We’re with you every step of the way with a roadmap, advice, and tips to guide your transition to smarter collaboration.
 
 
 
 
 
LEARN MORE

subject: Coming Soon: Saturday Seminar from SIETAR USA!
body:
'Intercultural vs. Inclusion: One Looks Out, the Other Looks In!' - 9-Sept-2023 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
SATURDAY SEMINAR: 
'Intercultural vs. Inclusion: 
One Looks Out, the Other Looks In!'
 
Your Seminar Leader:
Jay Cafferata, MS, CDE
 
 
 
 
September 9, 2023 @ 12:00 PM - 4:00 PM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
Have 
YOU
 registered yet? 
Don't miss this Saturday Seminar!  
Jay Cafferata
 will focus on how we unknowingly and unfortunately perpetuate racist ideology, colonialism, oppression, and discrimination in the words we use.  We'll be discussing the breakdown in communication between intercultural and inclusion dialogues. When we think about intercultural, we think international, global or worldwide – but when we think about inclusion, we think local, internal and the workplace. Why are we having these different conversations to the same discourse? What is the breakdown between these two seemingly different sets of vocabulary?
This interactive 4-hour session will include videos, polling, and breakout sessions. Participants are encouraged to join using a device that has a camera and a microphone as well as a secondary device like a phone or computer that allows for multiple windows to be open at the same time for the polling.
Participants will discuss and reflect on:
The words we use to describe others
Historical perspectives on these two lexicons
Global vs Local
The direction of impact: who is studying who?
At the conclusion of the presentation, participants will have:
A greater recognition of how inclusion and intercultural fit together.
The basic awareness of how we present ourselves in an environment or culture that is not necessarily our own.
Strategies to be more aware of where we are as professionals.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Registration Fees
$20 for Students
$45 for current SIETAR USA members in good standing
$65 for non-members
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Student-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Non-Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Your Seminar Leader
Jay Cafferata, MS, CDE
Mr. Cafferata is a well-known speaker and advocate for issues involving Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging. He considers himself a Social Justice Warrior and has spent decades as an advocate for the Sexual and Gender Minority Community. He has over 20 years of experience working with families of children with special needs. He has a master’s degree in communication studies from University of Nevada, Reno. and an associate degree in Deaf Studies from Western Nevada College. Mr. Cafferata is also a Certified Diversity Executive. He can be reached at 
jay@asltraining.com
.

subject: How Can We Achieve Pay Equity in Today’s Workforce?
body:
Let SHRM help find the solutions you need to address pay equity.
 
 
Is your organization facing challenges navigating pay equity? 
 
You play a key role in cultivating a work environment where 
employees feel they are being rewarded fairly
 based on performance, skills and other job requirements. Fair and equitable compensation allows organizations to retain top talent and ensures employers stay competitive when searching for talent in the same labor market. 
 
Let SHRM help you
 tackle pay disparities through over $13,000 worth of premier tools and resources, the latest news and a trusted partner to help make pay equity a reality. 
 
 
 
JOIN NOW
 
 
 
FEATURED RESOURCES
 
 
 
 
 
 
Compensation Data Reports
 
 
Receive 
FREE
 real-time reports to keep salaries competitive in this fluctuating salary market.
 
 
 
 
 
How to Establish Salary Ranges
 
 
Develop a compensation structure tailored to the needs and goals of your organization.
 
 
 
 
 
 
Managing Pay Equity
 
 
Use this toolkit effectively to recruit and retain employees while navigating federal, state and local laws, as well as internal policies.
 
 
 
 
 
Foundations of Compensation
 
 
Build your knowledge in the fundamentals of compensation in this practical yet engaging learning experience.

subject: It's time to reclaim your time.
body:
Time is a precious resource. Learn how to reclaim it and live a happier life. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
BOOKS
COLLECTIONS
TOOLS
CASE STUDIES
HBR STORE
 
 
Are you feeling starved for time?
 
 
You’re not alone. Four out of five adults report feeling that they have too much to do and not enough time to do it. How can we escape the time traps that make us feel this way and keep us from living our best lives?
In 
Time Smart: Tools for Reclaiming Your Time and Living a Happier Life
, you can learn to take back the time you lose to mindless tasks so you can live a happier, more time-affluent life.
 
LEARN MORE
 
 
Within this toolkit you’ll find these valuable resources:
An ebook copy of 
Time Smart
Quick Study Video featuring author Ashley Whillans
Downloadable exercises and strategies described in the book
Additional worksheets and tips to help free up time that you can reinvest in positive, healthy activities
Assessments, checklists, and exercises to support you in achieving the mindset shift that will make time-saving activities part of your everyday regime
Time is a precious resource. This toolkit will help you make the shift to time-smart living and, in the process, build a happier, more fulfilling life. 
 
 
Discover more tools
Find the tools you need to succeed.
 
SHOP NOW

(Photo credit: AirBnb/Elle Magazine)
Barbie's ROI — did the $150 million marketing strategy work?
 
Yes! 
Everyone is talking about Barbie. The movie, the colour pink and the huge 
'Barbie Dreamhouse' Malibu mansion
. Even the 'Barbenheimer' phenomenon has taken over social media platforms, creating organic and lead-generating content for both films!
 
Variety
 spoke to Warner Bros President of Global Marketing about the Barbie marketing strategy. The team has used a breadcrumb strategy — with trailers, social media templates (remember that from 6 months ago?) and major collaborations with 
AirBnb
 
and 
Xbox
. 
 
SEMrush
 
stated that there have been 2.6 million monthly searches for 'Barbie' and an additional 494K new backlinks to 
barbiethemovie.com
 in the last month.
 
The film made $337 million in Box Office opening weekend — now that's ROI.
Read the full Variety article 
here.
 
(Photo credit: InStyle/Crocs Instagram)
Everything is Pink: All the brands collaborating with Barbie.
 
Brands across the globe are taking advantage of the pink Barbie movement. With names like Crocs, NYX Cosmetics and Cotton On all getting involved. Even Burger King has launched a pink sauce burger. Check out more 
here.

 and

 orders.

Strategies for Conflict Resolution: Playing to Partner > Playing to Win
Conflict is unavoidable in the workplace, as people bring their dissenting opinions, concerns and own challenges to the table. In fact, the average employee in the U.S. spends 
2.8 hours a week
 dealing with conflict. Learning leaders are not immune to these challenges — especially when it comes to proving the value of training to business leaders and key stakeholders. Download the guide below to learn the strategies you need for conflict resolution.

Prove the value and impact of your training initiatives by creating alignment between organizational goals, your learning and development (L&D) plan and your leadership development program's goals. subject: Is Extra-role Performance the X-factor Your Team is Missing?
body:
Tried and tested tips for cultivating extra-role performance.
 
 
 
Hi Hannah,
 
When it comes to analyzing how people perform at work, most organizations focus on in-role performance, i.e. whether employees are meeting or exceeding specific KPIs that are tied directly to their job.
  
But there’s another indicator that may be just as impactful: extra-role performance.
  
This means self-motivated behavior that benefits the organization but is not directly tied to an employee’s role. This could be anything from assisting colleagues when they're overloaded or helping new team members adapt to the company culture, to making suggestions for improvement or conserving company resources during tough times.
  
In this week’s blog post, we look at why extra-role performance can be such a powerful X-factor for businesses, and outline some simple steps companies can take to cultivate it.
  
Find out more here.
  
Free Webinar TODAY!
From Day One’s virtual conference ‘
Keys to Employee Satisfaction, Recognition, and Retention
’ takes place TODAY (July 26) from noon to 4.30pm Eastern Time, and I’m thrilled to be on the panel for the ‘Bridging the Distance: How Tech Can Boost Engagement and Recognition’ webinar from 1.20pm-2pm ET.
  
Tickets are usually priced $149, but Attuned newsletter subscribers can 
sign up for a free VIP Ticket here
.
 
I hope to see you there!
 
Casey
Casey Wahl
Founder & CEO
P.S. Want to know more about how Attuned can help you improve communication and increase motivation? 
Take a tour!
 
P.P.S. Want even more in-depth insights? Download our free White Papers on 
Extrinsic Motivation vs Intrinsic Motivation
, 
Psychological Safety in the Hybrid Work Era
, and 
The Power of the Nudge
, as well as our newly released 
The State of Motivation Report 2023
.
 
If this was forwarded to you, subscribe here!

subject: This speaker has cracked the DE&I code on fostering collaboration
body:
How can you build bridges across a diverse workforce so that productivity and innovation thrives? 
 
 
True INCLUSION goes beyond race & gender 
Nearly two-thirds of organizations say DE&I is a strategic priority, yet only 
49 percent
 believe their culture is 
consistently supportive of DE&I across all divisions or geographies
.¹ 
How can you build bridges across a diverse workforce so that 
productivity
 and 
innovation
 thrive? 
 
  
Our closing speaker, 
Rich Tafel
, Entrepreneur, Advocate, Pastor and CEO of Public Squared, knows a thing or two about bridging the divide and bringing people together. 
An expert in navigating 
complex cultural differences
, Rich’s experience in the public policy sphere includes building successful coalitions with representatives from both sides of the aisle to treat AIDS and support same-sex marriage. 
A minister by training and graduate of Harvard Divinity School, Rich is a pastor of the Church of Holy City in Washington D.C. where he focuses on embracing an inclusive spirituality across generations. As the Director of Social Capital Advisors at Marcum LLP, he works with both for-profit and nonprofit organizations to build business models that will create formative change. 
Diversity of thought can be a catalyst for 
positive cultural change
, which is why we’re thrilled to conclude 
INCLUSION 2023
 with an advocate for unity. 
  
 
INCLUSION 2023 takes place 
Oct. 30- Nov. 1
 in 
Savannah, GA.,
 and 
virtually
. Join us to learn from experts like Rich along with 
75+ other speakers
 and 
50+ sessions
 covering cognitive diversity, unconscious bias, employee well-being and more! 
REGISTER NOW
 
 
  
CHECK OUT THIS 
PRECONFERENCE OPPORTUNITY 
  
 
 
 
Inclusive Workplace Culture:
Leading and Sustaining a Culture Transformation
* 
 
John Baldino
 
SHRM-SCP, MSHR, SPHR 
 
Numerous research studies conﬁrm that diverse workforces lead in innovation, productivity and proﬁtability. The key to unlocking these organizational benefits is to... 
 
LEARN MORE
 
 
  
¹ Source: 
Diversity, Equity, & Inclusion Status Update
. SHRM, 2021.
* Additional fee and registration required.
 
  
 
 
Connect with us on social!
 
  
  
  
  
 
1800 Duke Street, Alexandria, Virginia 22314 USA 
Contact Us

subject: Join Our July Community Call Today at 3:30PM ET
body:
Join us TODAY at 3:30PM ET for our July Community Call with Founder & CEO of Change Cadet, Dr. Akilah Cadet
 
Hi Hannah,
 
Join us 
TODAY
 at 
3:30PM ET 
for our
 July Community Call where JBC VP Adrienne Lawrence will be joined by
 Dr. Akilah Cadet, Founder & CEO of Change Cadet 
to discuss softness with boundaries leading DEI work.
 
As DEI professionals, we wholeheartedly advocate for creating inclusive spaces and empowering diverse voices. But amidst our dedication to others, it's critical to take time for self-care. Self-care is not selfish; it's essential for sustaining our passion and impact.
 
Join us for this important conversation and learn strategies to lead DEI work without losing yourself.
 
Register Here
 
Warmest Regards,
 
Jennifer Brown

,

subject: Successful Training Starts With Strategic Planning
body:
Take the Strategic Planning Workshop from Training Industry Courses.
View this email in your browser
.
 
Strategic planning, including the ability to connect training initiatives to organizational goals, is an essential business skill that many training professionals have not yet mastered.
To excel in strategic planning, you must have a deep understanding of your organization, including:
What are your organization's long-term goals?
Who are the people that make up your organization?
What are the PESTLE (political, economic, social, technological, environmental and legal) factors that impact your organization?
What are your organization's SWOTs (strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats)?
With the 
Strategic Planning Workshop
 from 
Training Industry Courses
, you will be guided through a series of 
tools and templates
 to help you answer these and more questions to hone your strategic planning skills and develop a strategic learning and development (L&D) plan for your organization. Click below to learn more about the 
Strategic Planning Workshop
.

subject: How Can We Achieve Pay Equity in Today’s Workforce?
body:
Let SHRM help find the solutions you need to address pay equity.
 
 
Is your organization facing challenges navigating pay equity? 
 
You play a key role in cultivating a work environment where 
employees feel they are being rewarded fairly
 based on performance, skills and other job requirements. Fair and equitable compensation allows organizations to retain top talent and ensures employers stay competitive when searching for talent in the same labor market. 
 
Let SHRM help you
 tackle pay disparities with over $13,000 worth of premier tools and resources, the latest news and a trusted partner to help make pay equity a reality. 
 
 
 
JOIN NOW
 
 
 
FEATURED RESOURCES
 
 
 
 
 
 
Compensation Data Reports
 
 
Receive 
FREE
 real-time reports to keep salaries competitive in this fluctuating salary market.
 
 
 
 
 
How to Establish Salary Ranges
 
 
Develop a compensation structure tailored to the needs and goals of your organization.
 
 
 
 
 
 
Managing Pay Equity
 
 
Use this toolkit effectively to recruit and retain employees while navigating federal, state and local laws, as well as internal policies.
 
 
 
 
 
Foundations of Compensation
 
 
Build your knowledge in the fundamentals of compensation in this practical yet engaging learning experience.

subject: My latest blog post
body:
View this email in your browser
 
Dear 
Hannah,
My latest blog post is up:
I Ran 100 Miles. Here’s What I Learned About Mindset, Community, and Persistence. 
Photo credit: Eddy Mo
The Western States Event
That’s me, on June 24, 2023, 55.7 miles into a 100-mile endurance run.
It wasn’t my first race at the 100-mile distance, but it was my first (and maybe only) shot at the 
Western States Endurance Run
, the oldest 100-mile foot race in North America, and possibly the world (having started in 1974).
Its epic sweep takes runners from Olympic Valley, California (near Lake Tahoe), up and over high mountain passes and ridges, down through dizzyingly steep canyons, like a descending roller coaster, to the Middle Fork of the American River and, ultimately, the Sierra foothills town of Auburn, California, where runners finish on the track at Placer High School. By the finish, runners have climbed about 18,000 feet and descended about 23,000. 
You’re catching me at rock bottom. After a day with stretches of gratitude, wonder, and practiced focus, at some point something changed, and I’ve just spent 17-plus steep, dusty miles, and about 5 ½ hours, saying mean things to myself about how slowly I’m moving, how bad I am at executing race plans at this distance, how much faster I should be moving with the cool conditions…you name it.
But I’m getting ahead of myself.
Since 2017 I’d been training hard to finish long “qualifier” trail races and earn a spot in the (in)famous annual lottery for a coveted spot in “States,” as the race is affectionately known in the ultramarathon-running (or, “ultrarunning”) community. Lottery day — the first Saturday each December — yielded disappointment after disappointment, even as my ticket count doubled each year.
Finally, last December 3, I awoke to a text message from a former coach, telling me my name had been drawn. Colette — my spouse, life partner, and fellow ultrarunner — and I were giddy, and immediately kicked into planning mode: Who should be my crew, taking care of me at various points along the route? Who should be my pacers, accompanying me over the final 40ish miles? Was there somewhere we could stay the week before the race, to help acclimatize to the 6,200-foot elevation of the start line at Olympic Valley? And many, many more questions.
Fast-forward to 5:00 a.m. on June 24, when the race officially began. Everything from training to logistics to the cooler-than-expected weather forecast had gone as well as I’d hoped for, or better. A head cold two days before the race was an unhappy surprise, but I wasn’t about to withdraw and send myself back to the lottery. I knew this was probably my only shot at finishing States: it could take years to get back into the race, and at 55, I’ve begun feeling the steepening downhill trend that inevitably comes with age.
Head cold be damned: this was it.
Even for the fastest runners, the tale of a 100-mile race is long: full of literal and figurative ups and downs, moments of despair and exhilaration, and chance after chance for epiphanies great and small. For folks who run at a pace like I ran States in 2023, the tale is longer still. So, you may be relieved to know that I’m not here to tell you the story of my whole race. I may tell that story one day, but not here, not now. Today, I’ll simply share a bit about the moment in the photo, how it fed into the rest of my race, and how it’s helped me learn and relearn some key life lessons that anyone can apply.
Beware the Chair
It’s bedrock wisdom in the ultrarunning community: unless you need to change your shoes, tend to an injury, or do something else that really, truly 
requires
 you to sit down, you should avoid sitting at all costs.
I arrive at Michigan Bluff aid station, Mile 55.7, greeted by an arch of brightly colored balloons, music pumping, and — the ultimate show of support in the trail-running community — cowbells ringing. I’m an hour ahead of the race cutoff (the absolute deadline for leaving the aid station) and desperately needing a “reset.”
Or, that’s what I’ve been telling myself. If you ask me what I mean by “reset,” I won’t be able to tell you anything coherent. I probably mean something like, “I want to feel like I felt at the start line.” Yeah, right.
I’ve been physically worn down by the relentless course, but even more, I’ve been battering myself with negative self-talk, mile after mile, hour after hour.
My stomach has also gone sideways. This is nothing new: it’s normal for me, and for most ultrarunners, to have a hard time getting calories in, and keeping them down, the deeper we get into an ultra. Even so, I’ve been beating myself up for not eating more.
My crew consists of Colette, my older daughter Mariette, and her fiancé, Eddy. Also at Michigan Bluff is Chuck, who will be pacing me — accompanying me on the trail — for the next 24 miles.
As I enter the aid station, ducking through the buoyant-but-low-hung balloon arch, Colette says, “Welcome to the party! It’s going to be a short party.”
My terse reply: “No it’s not!”
Even though I’ve given myself a decent cushion against the cutoff, Colette is eager to get me in and out of the aid station as quickly as possible. Foolishly, I ignore her and make a beeline for the chair.
I lament out loud: “I have not been able to get any calories. I want some broth. And if they have noodles, that’d be amazing.”
I’ve never run an ultra where I’m consistently able to take in 
anything
 sweet this far in. Back in November 2022, the last time Chuck paced me at a 100-miler, he offered me a taste of an energy gel at about Mile 76. I ate literally one drop and promptly dry-heaved.
This time I know better: I feel like I can actually take in savory calories through the broth, preferably supplemented with noodles.
As it turns out, they have rice with the broth, which works just as well. I begin sipping as quickly as I can, and shaking the bottle (which you can see in the picture) to try to get the rice out.
This is all good.
Less good? What the chair is starting to do to my psyche.
Ultrarunners know that the “pity party” is always beckoning. The many forms of discomfort we experience — physical and mental fatigue, sleep deprivation, muscle aches, blisters, and sundry other maladies — along with the knowledge that we’re nowhere near done, conspire to convince us that we’re bound to fail. Along with that comes a generalized sense of “woe is me”: the pity party.
In life outside of ultramarathons, I don’t like the term. It’s often used to dismiss the very real negative life outcomes faced by members of marginalized populations, brought about by unjust systems.
Within ultrarunning culture, though — in which each of us has not only chosen to race, but has spent countless hours training, and often non-trivial amounts of money, not to mention the sacrifices of our loved ones — “pity party” totally fits the bill.
There, in the chair, I sink more deeply into the pity party.
While tending to my physical needs by trying to consume calories, I’m neglecting the crucial mental side, on the verge of what could turn into a downward spiral, leading to a decision to drop from the race.
As I teeter on the edge, Chuck says to me, “If we get moving, you’ll feel better.”
I know it’s true. I’m not ready to move just yet, but his words steady me.
Colette follows with: “I’m glad you’re taking care of yourself. You’ve been moving so great.”
I don’t feel like I’ve been moving great, but it’s nice to hear this from Colette.
I futz with my headlamp, which I’ll be wearing for the next few hours as Chuck and I run together through the night. I manage to get it on, and it’s working well.
All around me, everywhere I look, it’s nothing but people who want me to succeed — like, really, really want me to succeed. Right now, it’s feeling like they want me to succeed more than I want to myself.
Mariette (with great conviction): “You’re gonna get through this.”
Eddy: “You’re doing great.”
Suddenly I’m standing. I don’t know how it’s happened, but I’ve left the gravitational pull of the chair.
Mike, a race official, says: “Get on down the road. You’re gonna do great. Keep it up.” To my crew, he adds: “You guys can walk him out. Walk him out. You should get him outta here.” To me, he adds: “Go get ‘em!”
Chuck and I start walking, along with Colette, Mariette, and Eddy. Slowly at first, gradually picking up speed.
Colette again: “I’m really amazed at the way you’re moving. Jaw-dropping, actually.”
I created a mantra around this a few ultras ago: “I don’t care how I’m feeling. I care how I’m moving.” It’s meant to remind me that I will always, always feel terrible after a certain number of miles, and so I shouldn’t dwell on it, focusing instead on doing everything I can to keep moving forward as well as I can, for as long as I can. Colette’s words call this mantra back to mind. I speed up a little.
Soon it’s time to part ways. Colette: “We love you and we’re gonna see you at Foresthill!” That’s the next aid station, 6.3 up-and-down miles away, at Mile 62.0.
The Finish
Spoiler alert: I eventually finished the race. (I promised you I wouldn’t tell you the whole story!)
My finish happened during what’s called the “Golden Hour”: the 30th and final hour of the race.
Golden Hour is a time of fierce celebration. Hundreds upon hundreds of people — runners, coaches, officials, crews, pacers, friends, family, and even the townspeople of Auburn — turn up at 10:00 a.m. to cheer their hearts out for the runners who’ve persevered the longest to reach the promised land of the Placer High track.
This year, 68 runners finished during Golden Hour: an average of over one per minute, making up over 20% of the 328 total finishers.
The race’s official rules allow anyone and everyone to join runners for the final 1.3 miles from the last aid station, at Robie Point, to the finish. I was joined by Colette (who’d been pacing me since Mile 94.3), Chuck (who’d snuck in a little sleep in his car since leaving me with Clare at Mile 79.8), Clare (who paced me from Mile 78.0 to Mile 94.3), Drew (who’d been coordinating crew from Foresthill and from his home in Auburn), Mariette, and Eddy. We ran together through the streets of Auburn, all smiles and whoops, cheered on by the locals, who mark this date in their calendars each June.
The finish was capped off by running together for 300 meters on the Placer High track.
Here I am, right after crossing the finish line, in 29 hours, 29 minutes, and 33 seconds.
Colette, me, and Chuck (Photo credit: Facchino Photography)
Lesson #1: Listen to the voices that serve you.
I’ve never sought out people to run with, treasuring the hours of precious “me time” on the trails.
Once, years ago, as I passed a group of runners going the opposite direction on a fire road on a long run, I thought to myself, “There goes one version of hell.”
I still love my solo training runs, but never have I felt more deeply in my bones that I truly, undeniably 
need
 others in order to succeed at ultrarunning. Western States has seen to that, and nowhere was it more apparent than at Michigan Bluff.
Every single word, every single movement of my crew was laser-focused on helping me succeed. To support me at aid stations along the way, they had braved a 3:00 a.m wakeup, narrow mountain roads, an hours-long line for a shuttle bus, and endless waiting for me to show up. Still to come after Michigan Bluff was more driving, along with a late bedtime, early wakeup, and, in Colette’s case, six miles of pacing me on steep trails to the finish. Followed by more walking, lifting, waiting, care-giving. And the two-hour drive home.
Chuck paced me for 24 miles through the night and barely slept. Clare paced me for 16 miles through the wee hours of early morning and barely slept. Drew spent all morning, afternoon, evening, and night making sure everyone knew where I was, and where they needed to be when — and barely slept.
Then, every one of them showed up at Robie Point to accompany me to the finish.
1,500 volunteers at 20 aid stations made similar sacrifices, as did the crews and pacers of all 379 runners who started the race.
For hours on end, I’d told myself I wasn’t good enough, fast enough, or smart enough to reach the finish line and earn my coveted belt buckle. I’d undermined myself by not eating well. I’d even convinced myself there was beauty in failing, and that I might choose that beauty over continued suffering.
My crew and my pacers didn’t know about any of that mental chatter, and if they had, they wouldn’t have cared. They believed in me. Every friend I saw along the way, every volunteer, every race official: they believed in me.
Sometimes we just need to ignore the doubts within, and let the love and support of others carry us where we need to go. Much more than any “strength of character” or “iron will,” that’s what got me across the finish line.
Chuck, Colette, me, Clare, Drew, Mariette, and Eddy (Photo credit: unknown)
Lesson #2: Ride the highs. Endure the lows.
The human mind is fickle, and it’s really good at tricking us into believing that our reality right now is all there is.
Sitting in that chair at Michigan Bluff, all I could feel was exhaustion and despair.
Much earlier, from Mile 31 to Mile 38, as I was speeding down the fastest part of the course, I saw nothing but glory in my future.
Earlier than that, I felt even better.
Mile 2: fresh as a daisy! (Photo credit: Pen Perez)
All of those thoughts and feelings were completely, totally, 100% true and real in the moment.
Since ups and downs just are, we’re well served by getting better at recognizing them, and at using them in helpful ways.
Highs offer the chance to “let it ride”: whatever we’re doing comes easily and efficiently. A lot of payoff for a small investment. Enjoy it while it lasts, and get as much done as you can.
Lows teach us to persist, and remind us that there’s always a brighter day ahead.
Just. Keep. Going.
Lesson #3: A Model for Humanity
An ultrarunner friend once asked me, rhetorically: where else other than an ultra is every single person you encounter desperately cheering for you to succeed?
I’ll add a corollary: What does the existence of such a community tell us about our potential as a species?
Systems — including systems of shared behaviors and values, i.e., cultures — create the context of human relationships, and the conditions of humans’ lives. Ultrarunning has managed to create a culture of deeply committed mutual care and support. I don’t see any ironclad logic that says we can’t create this kind of culture on a global scale. The obstacles are many, and we can’t see the finish line. In a way the journey toward a truly loving future for our species is the ultimate ultramarathon.
More to Come
Stay tuned for more posts with lessons from ultrarunning that we can apply in our daily lives and work.
Meanwhile, some more photos from after the race.
Dusty trails: not a tan line
All cleaned up and ready to receive my personally engraved belt buckle
The buckle!!!!!
 
If you have any thoughts to share, I'd love to hear them. You can just reply to this message.
Jason
 
Please reach out if you have any questions.
Send me a message
Sent to: 
h.strack@lcwmail.com
 
Unsubscribe
 
JP Global Lead LLC, 555 Pierce St., Albany, CA 94706, United States

subject: Training Industry Weekly Recap 📅 July 23, 2023
body:
Last call for magazine proposals, new State of the Industry report and more.
View this email in your browser
THE BUSINESS OF LEARNING™
To succeed in the world of learning and development (L&D), it’s important to keep up with emerging trends and business practices. That’s why we’re happy to share our latest research report, “
The State of the Sales Training Market
,” where you’ll find all of the key insights you need to gain a competitive edge and stay ahead in the sales market.
We also invite you to download the 
Strategic Planning Toolkit
 to gain access to three helpful templates for aligning training with business goals. Lastly, we’re currently accepting article proposals for the
 2024 Editorial Calendar for Training Industry Magazine
. The deadline to submit an idea is July 31.
As always, we love to hear from you. Please send any comments, suggestions or article pitches to Email 
editor@trainingindustry.com
.
Danielle Murdaugh
Associate Editor
Last Call for Training Industry Magazine Proposals
Do you have an interesting perspective on the current and future state of corporate training? If so, then we want to hear from you! Training Industry is currently accepting article proposals for the 2024 Editorial Calendar for 
Training Industry Magazine
, an award-winning publication that connects L&D professionals with the resources they need to manage the business of learning. We want to hear your insights, strategies and solutions for managing world-class training. Submit your ideas by 
July 31
.
Learn More
 
[State of the Industry Report] The Sales Training Market
Staying up to date on the latest research and trends is time-consuming but essential. Luckily, we’ve done the research and gathered the insights for you in our new report, “
The State of the Sales Training Market
.” In this report, you’ll find all the information you need to gain a competitive edge and stay ahead in the sales market. With data on trends, modalities, market projections, sourcing practices and more, our newly released report on the sales training market has the answers you need.
Get the Report
 
The Roadmap to Strategic Planning
Creating a strategic plan is no easy feat. It doesn’t get easier when you factor in the added layer of challenges that come with L&D, making the proper connections to demonstrate value and communicating why it should matter to stakeholders. But have no fear! We have crafted and packaged the solution for you. Download the
 Strategic Planning Toolkit
 for access to three templates that will help you begin the journey of aligning your L&D function to organizational goals.
Access the Toolkit

subject: [Webinar] Moments to Momentum: How to Supercharge Sales Readiness With Conversation Intelligence
body:
Join us for this complimentary webinar.
View this email  in your browser
Moments to Momentum: How to Supercharge Sales Readiness With Conversation Intelligence
 
  
27
JUL
2023
@ 1 p.m. ET
  
Register Now
Traditional sales learning strategies often rely on modeling behaviors from top sellers. However, sometimes the best sellers don't have the best behaviors. In fact, 84% of buyers say reps don’t convey value effectively.
Great sales learning strategies are only as good as the quality of the sales conversations they produce.
By leveraging conversation intelligence (CI), sales leaders get more visibility into these conversations and can easily identify and model best behaviors across all your sellers, targeting your learning activities to where, and who, it matters most.
In this 30-minute live session, Jake Miller, senior product marketing manager at Allego, will cover:
Key factors to identify quality sales conversations without CI.
Why CI is critical for understanding the value and efficacy of sales learning programs.
How to uncover competency gaps and take action.
The importance of sharing best practices.
Register Now
Our webinars are pre-qualified for 
one credit hour
 with leading HR and training certifications.

subject: Language & Culture Worldwide - 2024 From Day One HR/DEI/CPO Leaders
body:
Hannah,
 
Excited to share our 2024 calendar of live and virtual people meetings for the HR/DEI and CPO Community.  Please see the press release below but wanted to make sure to bubble this up in your inbox.  Could we set up a call next week to touch base on the calendar and opportunities?
 
How's Monday or Tuesday? Would 3pm either day work for you?
 
Excited to connect and discuss getting Language & Culture Worldwide involved! 
   
 
Best, 
Missy 
Top executives in HR, Diversity, Corporate Culture, Employee Engagement, and Corporate Social Responsibility discuss hybrid work, social impact, employee engagement, and more
 
 
 
FROM DAY ONE 2024 IN-PERSON CONFERENCE SCHEDULE  
 
 
* indicates exact date is confirmed.
*ATLANTA, GA — January 2
*HOUSTON, TX — February 6
*SEATTLE, WA — February 20
*SILICON VALLEY, CA — February 22
SALT LAKE CITY, UT — March 12
*WASHINGTON, D.C. — March 26
BROOKLYN, NY — April 9
BOSTON, MA — April 18
CHICAGO, IL — April 21
DALLAS, TX — May 7
*MINNEAPOLIS, MN — May 14
 
AUSTIN, TX — June 6
SAN FRANCISCO, CA — June 26
BOSTON, MA — September 12
NASHVILLE, TN — October 1
PHILADELPHIA, PA — October 8 
MANHATTAN, NY — October 22
DENVER, CO — October 29
 
 
LOS ANGELES, CA — November 12
 
 
MIAMI, FL — November 26
 
 
SAN FRANCISCO, CA — December 3
FROM DAY ONE 2023 VIRTUAL CONFERENCE SCHEDULE
Jan. 10, 2024 - 
A Fresh Commitment to a Culture of Well-Being
While many employers recognize the connection between well-being and productivity, creating a healthy balance in the real world of work can be challenging. What are the key choices and thoughtful compromises that must be made for workers to thrive as well as produce? How can managers be trained to make the well-being of their workers a top priority? How can companies get a better sense of which benefits and rewards are most effective–and encourage workers to take advantage of them. 
Feb. 14, 2024 - 
Getting to the Next Stage of Diversity and Belonging 
At a time of resistance and corporate austerity, DEI advocates will need to re-energize themselves and their organizations with new ideas, programs, and reasoning for the cause of diversity. What can DEI practitioners learn from companies with consistent success? How are companies changing their policies to respond to court rulings and lawsuits? What practices have brought the most progress in bringing diversity to leadership rank
 
March 6, 2024 - 
Employee Engagement: Tapping the Secrets of Energizing Workers 
Companies want their employees to be enthused and involved, yet employers need to be thoughtful in fostering these qualities in authentic ways. What’s the latest thinking about how employers can understand the motivations of their workers–and how to respond? What are the best methods for recognizing achievement, both individually and among teams? What’s the connection between engagement and job satisfaction? In the hybrid work environment, what binds workers together and wards off anxiety and loneliness?
 
April 3, 2024 - 
Benefits that Fit Individual Needs Without Busting the Budge
Having made a commitment to recognize the unique needs of individuals, the secret is in the execution. What are the emerging benefits and rewards that workers are seeking, from fertility care to financial wellness? How can companies use technology to stay in close touch with what individuals are experiencing–and where they need help as a result? How can companies choose among myriad point solutions and innovative new platforms? What are the most cost-effective rewards in terms of investments and outcomes
May 22, 2024 - 
The Art and Science of Employee Retention, Coaching and Advancement
While the pace of job-hopping has eased, employers have a powerful motivation to retain skilled workers, both for financial and cultural reasons. How can employers use new tools, including AI, to gain insights about what’s inspiring their workers to stay committed–or walk out the door? Since attrition is often caused by poor relationships with managers, what are innovative ways for employers to train their workers to be better leaders at a time when workers have higher expectations for job satisfaction? How can technology help make coaching more effective?
June 12, 2024 - 
Bringing Talent Acquisition into the Digital Age
Despite layoffs making headlines now, all the demographic and digital trends point toward tough competition for workers in the future–maybe sooner than most expect. What are the new techniques and tools that talent-acquisition can use to envision the workforce their company will need in the future? What data and insights can HR and TA leaders provide to the company to be ahead of trends? How can companies do a better job of internal recruiting and promoting internal mobility? What are the best practices for hiring based on skills and potential, rather than credentials?
 
July 10, 2024 - 
Learning and Development: How New Tools Are Changing Upskilling and Career Mobility 
 
 
As employers put more emphasis on skills as the currency for worker development, they’re seeking new ways to measure them, fill in gaps, and predict the skills needed in the future. How can these new tools, including AI, create better matches between employees and projects? How can employers gain insights from the data they gather? Why do real-world simulations help measure certain skills better than traditional assessments? 
 
July 17, 2024 - 
Innovative Benefits That Support Healthy Families and Caregivers
 
 
As the pandemic’s caregiving crisis showed, employers found significant gaps in their support for the parents and other caregivers in their workforces. The resulting scramble to help has produced a wealth of new HR policies, benefit offerings, and management practices. Where is the greatest demand for support, as well as the most innovative new methods? What have been the most cost-effective ways to help caregivers of all kinds, including parents as well as “sandwich generation” workers caring for elderly and disabled relatives? 
 
Aug. 7, 2024 - 
Employee Engagement: Using Technology to Gain Insight Into Work Needs and Ambitions 
 
Traditional methods like town-hall meetings and surveys can be effective, but data and well-drawn insights can give top leaders a heads up about evolving patterns and trends in their workforces. How can AI and other technology be deployed in a way that brings new insights yet still respects privacy and the individual human factors at play? What approaches will bring employers new empathy for worker needs, ambitions, and well-being? 
 
 
 
Aug. 28, 2024 - 
Pursuing Higher Productivity With Human Factors in Mind
 
 
In a competitive and uncertain climate, most companies need to do more with less. Yet if workers are their greatest asset, employers need to make sure the push for greater output is sustainable. What is the latest thinking about how to measure productivity, the means for stimulating it, and ensuring that workers have the energy to meet their goals–as well as thrive over the long run?
Sept. 18, 2024 - 
Building a Corporate Culture That Workers Can Understand, Influence and Embrace  
Company culture is amorphous yet vital–the shared beliefs, values, traditions and behaviors that drive the actions of individuals and the organization as a whole. Who should be the architects of a company’s culture and how should it be designed and constructed? How should the culture be communicated, broadly and in everyday actions? How should a company start out on a project to evolve its culture in a credible way?  
Oct. 16, 2024 - 
Modernizing Your Workplace for a More Flexible, Inclusive Era
 
 
The arrival of hybrid work sent virtually every employer back to the drawing board about what the workplace should look like, including floor plans, digital platforms, meetings, and even office furniture. After more than three years of experimenting, what have innovative companies discovered about what works–and what doesn’t? How have they improved workplace environments to be healthier, as well as more productive? How have these changes affected the goals of diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging?
 
 
Nov. 20, 2024 - 
Finding and Deploying HR Tech That Will Empower Workers  
 
 
The blossoming of innovation in HR technology has given employers untold new abilities to organize, inspire, develop, reward, and care for their workers. Yet this revolution presents new challenges for companies in choosing and supervising these tech tools. How should these tech platforms be evaluated? Which departments of the company should take responsibility–and how can organizations coordinate these moves? How can companies make sure they’re empowering their workers rather than overloading them with adaptation and distraction?
 
 
Dec. 11, 2024 - 
Pioneering Approaches to Digital Transformation and the Future of Work
 
 
The emergence of generative AI in 2023 marked the arrival of a transforming technology that will change human roles, add and subtract jobs, and create astounding new capabilities. How can companies manage the transition, both from the short-term competitive pressures to  long-term corporate survival? How can AI be used to unleash creativity? Where are the areas for abuse, intentional or otherwise? How will digital transformation affect fields from talent acquisition to learning and development? 
 
 
 
 
 
Missy Morrison 
From Day One
www.fromdayone.co

subject: Charlotte's Fall career fairs are filling quickly
body:
Hello Hannah,
We invite you to make career fairs part of your Fall recruiting strategy. In this email, we share information on Fall career fairs, which typically sell out a month or more in advance. 
We're sharing this email with all active contacts in Hire-A-Niner (without a way to filter out contacts who have already registered for fairs). Want to see if your organization is already registered for fairs? Take a look at the employers registered for the 
Fall Career & Internship Fair
 and 
Part-time Job Fair
.
September 15, 10am-2pm
UNC Charlotte's 
Fall Career & Internship Fair
 (in-person event) provides organizations with an excellent opportunity for branding and recruiting candidates for full-time jobs, internships, and co-ops. Draws students/alumni from all of the University's colleges*. 2,000 students/alumni are expected to attend. Registration fees for attending the Fall Career Fair: Corporate - $525  //  Gov/Nonprofit - $295  //  Staffing/Recruiting Firms - $795 [because of space limitations, we're unable to have graduate programs at this event]
Registration is 50% full; we recommend registering by early August. We're exploring additional space options to accommodate more employers.
*Construction Management, Civil Engineering, Financial Services, Nursing, Actuarial Science, and Architecture departments host their own recruiting events. For departmental contacts, see the Other Campus Career Fairs section of 
https://careerfairs.charlotte.edu
 . Few Nursing, Counseling, Construction Management, and Architecture students attend the Fall Fair. 
October 4, 11am-2pm
UNC Charlotte's 
Part-time Job Fair
 (in-person event) provides organizations with an excellent opportunity for recruiting candidates for positions that don't require a college degree: part-time, temporary, seasonal, or full-time non-degreed jobs. This in-person job fair will be held at the Student Union on UNC Charlotte's main campus. Employer Registration Fees: General: $175 // Staffing Agencies/Third Party Vendors: $250
Registration is 40% full; we recommend registering by mid-August. 
 
Other Upcoming Events
Inclusivity Mixer
 - September 12, 5-8pm
Opportunity for branding, networking, and recruiting from a diverse group of candidates. Enjoy this free mock-tail mixer that draws ~100 students and alumni whose career interests are across multiple industries and come from a variety of majors. 
 
This email was sent to all Hire-A-Niner contacts who have been active in the last 3 years and have opted to receive emails. 
To unsubscribe or change your notification settings, log into Hire-A-Niner.
University Career Center
University of North Carolina at Charlotte
9201 University City Blvd, Atkins Building, Room 150
Charlotte, NC 28223
(704) 687-0795

subject: RE: Anti-Racism and JEDI proposal - [LCW]
body:
Dear Hannah,
 
I hope you are keeping well. I wanted to provide you with an update on our RFP process. Thank you so much for taking the time and interest to submit a proposal. We want to thank you and your team for the time and energy you invested in drafting a solid and impressive proposal. The Selection Committee was very impressed with your team’s approach, resume and wealth of experience.
 
This selection process was highly competitive with excellent proposals, making our decision very difficult. Though your qualifications and approach are impressive, after carefully reviewing all the proposals received, the selection committee has chosen to proceed with another candidate whose approach is better aligned with our organizational needs at this time. 
 
We were very 
pleased
 with your proposal and really do appreciate your interest in Oxfam Canada. We believe that there will be other projects we can work on together in the future. It is our hope that you will keep us in mind for future collaborations.
 
Thank you once again for participating in this process and for your interest with Oxfam Canada.
 
We wish you all the best in the future.
 
Kind regards,
Halimah Ahmed
 
From:
 Hannah Strack <
h.strack@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Monday, April 24, 2023 12:03 PM
To:
 CAN - FA - RFP <
can.fa.rfp@oxfam.ca
>; Carolina Palacios <
carolina.palacios@oxfam.org
>
Cc:
 Melissa Neu <
m.neu@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Anti-Racism and JEDI proposal - [LCW]
 
Dear Carolina and Oxfam Canada RFP Committee, 
 
We are delighted to present LCW’s response to Oxfam Canada’s selection of preferred vendor for the Anti-Racism and JEDI RFP. We are grateful that you reached out to our company and would be thrilled to partner with you through this initiative. LCW has helped global organizations craft custom solutions that advance cultural competency for more than two decades. Like you, LCW has a history of promoting diversity and inclusion, and we believe sharing perspectives foster deeper connections and enriched collaboration. By partnering with organizations of all sizes, we have dedicated our efforts to help organizations identify and mitigate biases so that they represent the communities in which they operate.
 
Please do not hesitate to contact me with any questions about the proposal. We are grateful for this opportunity and look forward to hearing from you soon.
 
Sincerely,
Hannah Strack

Business Development Associate

subject: July Community Call with Dr. Akilah Cadet
body:
Join us on Tuesday July 25th for our next Community Call with Dr. Akilah Cadet as we discuss softness with boundaries leading DEI work.
 
Hi Hannah,
 
This month, we'll be hosting a special community call on 
TUESDAY
 
July 25th, at 3:30PM ET.
 
As DEI professionals, we wholeheartedly advocate for creating inclusive spaces and empowering diverse voices. But amidst our dedication to others, it's critical to take time for self-care. Self-care is not selfish; it's essential for sustaining our passion and impact.
 
Join JBC VP 
Adrienne Lawrence
 in conversation with 
Dr. Akilah Cadet
 as they discuss softness with boundaries leading DEI work. Those who champion DEI work recognize there's a blurred line between pushing for cultural change and practicing self-care. They'll discuss strategies to lead the work without losing oneself.

subject: Caught in the middle of the culture war
body:
Invite to a special webinar on Aug 3rd ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hi 
Hannah.
You may have seen the articles about 13 state attorneys general threatening DEI programs at corporations with legal actions shortly after SCOTUS' decision on Affirmative Action. Then 20 other attorneys general responded to reassure corporations that their aspirational hiring goals and demographic reporting were legal. 
Then there's Target. Remember Target's Pride situation? They received pressure from 7 Republican attorneys general saying Pride month campaigns could violate state child protection laws. Double the amount of Democratic attorneys general wrote to say that state laws against discrimination protect the retailer. 
You may not be getting these letters, but you're not immune to the effects 
😳
Companies are in the middle of the culture war and as I've said many times, most organizations are woefully unprepared. Here's another example. 
I reviewed content from a company based in Florida that was contacted by an LGBTQ+ advocacy group that let the company know that the political donation it made was to a politician who supports the anti-LGBTQ+ legislation in the state. Since the company had an employee contingent marching in the local Pride parade wearing the company's shirts, etc. they may want to know. 
The company responded defensively highlighting a list of community service, basically. They spoke to apples when the advocacy group was talking about oranges. 
I'll share what I recommended to them and even draw some stick figures to help paint the picture we're finding ourselves in at a special webinar on Thurs Aug 3, 10am PT/1pm ET.
REGISTER FOR THE SPECIAL WEBINAR:
CAUGHT IN THE CULTURE WAR: COMMS' ROLE
We need to talk about how we're getting caught in the middle of something our companies feel that they are beyond, or tried to ignore or tried to duck and cover from. 
Well, friends, there are fewer and fewer places to hide and we haven't yet hit rock bottom. In the webinar, I'll help connect the dots and speak to how we can be significant drivers to help our organizations navigate our way through this critical time.
We have options!
As long as we have options, there is hope! I've had several conversations with several clients about what's going on and what I see the trajectory we're on is leading to. I'll share these conversations with you at the webinar. 
Come with your questions and be ready to take notes. There will be action steps. :)
In the meantime, stay in the work. Don't get distracted. Be unwavering. 
See you on July 28th for Book Club, Aug 1 for Ask Me Anything and Aug 3rd for the special webinar. Hang on to your hats and buckle up. We can do this. 
kim
PS: Some homework: 
check out this article
 before the webinar and let's talk about it. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
New Podcast Episode 
 
This week's Communicate Like You Give a Damn episode is with Kimb Massey, Ph.D. She talks about culture and the influence of media on stereotypes that have formed the progress and resistance to DEI efforts in the workplace and society. Now you have six episodes to catch up on! 
 
It's a podcast made just for you. 
Listen, Subscribe, Share Now

subject: How can you shape company culture with a remote workforce?
body:
Break down geographical barriers with these insights.
 
 
 
Hi Hannah,
 
A strong company culture is a crucial component of any successful organization. Not only does it create a sense of belonging among employees that has been shown to boost engagement, performance, and retention, but it also enhances communication, motivation, and the ability to create a psychologically safe environment.
  
But while it’s important, it’s not always easy—especially in the remote/hybrid work era, when employees are often distributed around the world and communication is frequently virtual, asynchronous, or both.
  
This was the challenge tech startup Alphaus faced as they entered a phase of hyper-growth. With an expanding workforce spread across multiple locations in Japan, Malaysia, and elsewhere, they wanted to evolve the company from a “cozy, family-like, small team” into a “well-organized, governed group of specialists to pursue higher business goals that cannot be achieved by maintaining the previous team dynamic,” while also maintaining and strengthening the distinctive company culture they had developed from the start.
  
Want to know how they did it? 
Read this.
 
Join us at From Day One for free!
Attuned is thrilled to be part of From Day One’s upcoming virtual conference ‘
Keys to Employee Satisfaction, Recognition, and Retention
’, which takes place from noon to 4.30pm Eastern Time on Wednesday July 26—and we’re offering our newsletter subscribers the chance to join for free!
  
I’ll be on the panel for 
‘Bridging the Distance: How Tech Can Boost Engagement and Recognition’ from 1.20pm-2pm ET,
 alongside Tyler Weeks, Vice President, Talent Analytics at Marriott; Rekha Gurnani, Senior Director, Global Compensation & People Analytics at Box; and Marie Potter, Senior Director of Culture and Development at Getty Images.
Tickets for the conference, which provide access to all sessions, are usually priced $49-$149, but you can 
register for a free Attuned VIP Ticket here
.
 
I hope to see you there!
 
Casey
Casey Wahl
Founder & CEO
P.S. Want to know more about how Attuned can help you improve communication and increase motivation? 
Take a tour!
 
P.P.S. Want even more in-depth insights? Download our free White Papers on 
Extrinsic Motivation vs Intrinsic Motivation
, 
Psychological Safety in the Hybrid Work Era
, and 
The Power of the Nudge
, as well as our newly released 
The State of Motivation Report 2023
.

subject: Join Us at the Better Together Conference on Oct 18-19
body:
Why does it seem increasingly difficult to be in conversation with each other? And, who’s missing from these conversations, as a result? 
 
Hi Hannah,
 
Why does it seem increasingly difficult to be in conversation with each other? 
And,
 who’s missing from these conversations, as a result?
 
In our many years of hosting the Better Man Conference and working with thousands of leaders, we’ve met so many who are eager to step into allyship. They know doing nothing isn’t an option, but aren’t certain where they fit into the inclusion equation. Many are striving to build competence, and confidence, to step up, and speak up, but are afraid to say the wrong thing, feeling guilty or even targeted and blamed as the problem. 
The conference was originally created to reframe this experience, and reset our understanding of
 everyone, of every identity
, as powerful change agents. 
But it 
has
 become more difficult than ever to practice the imperfect art of allyship - however we identify, because there are few spaces where we can return to the building blocks of inclusion - places where we can deepen our self-awareness, analyze how trust is built, unearth our story, and practice both sharing and listening. 
We are excited to announce the very first 
Better Together Conference
, a series of conversations aimed to foster learning, connection, trust, and empathy that include both male leaders and other champions, with the intent of articulating a vision for true partnership that includes and enlists 
all of us
. 
The conference was born out of - and will continue to center - the idea that we need safe spaces devoid of shame and blame, to ask questions, practice, and learn how to have meaningful and authentic conversations that build bridges across differences. If we don’t, we’ll never have equitable and inclusive cultures where everyone can thrive.
 
Learn more about the conference and secure your ticket while early-bird rates last. We hope you'll come back to the conversations that matter. Join us on 
October 18th-19th. 
Secure my Ticket
 
Join us Today for a LinkedIn Live to Learn More About the Better Together Conference
 
Have questions about the Better Together Conference? Join me and Better Man Movement Founder, Ray Arata today at 
12PM ET
 as we discuss the new conference format, agenda, and what you can expect.
 
Attend the LinkedIn Live
 
Group Ticket Packages & Sponsorships
 
There are currently limited group ticket packages and sponsorships available for organizations who want to be more involved in this transformational event. Please inquire below for more information.
 
Inquire Here
 
Warmest Regards,
 
Jennifer Brown
CEO & Founder, 
Jennifer Brown Consulting
Author, 
Inclusion
, 
How to Be an Inclusive Leader
, and 
Beyond Diversity
Host,

subject: HR is at the forefront of workplace evolution.

Registration is now OPEN for SHRM24. Join your peers in Chicago at the forefront of workplace evolution

subject: Ready for a Saturday Seminar from SIETAR USA?
body:
'Intercultural vs. Inclusion: One Looks Out, the Other Looks In!' - Sept 9, 2023 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
SATURDAY SEMINAR: 
'Intercultural vs. Inclusion: 
One Looks Out, the Other Looks In!'
 
Your Seminar Leader:
Jay Cafferata, MS, CDE
 
 
 
 
September 9, 2023 @ 12:00 PM - 4:00 PM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
In this first Saturday Seminar for 2023, self-professed Social Justice 
Warrior
 
Jay Cafferata
 will focus on how we unknowingly and unfortunately perpetuate racist ideology, colonialism, oppression, and discrimination in the words we use.  We'll be discussing the breakdown in communication between intercultural and inclusion dialogues. When we think about intercultural, we think international, global or worldwide – but when we think about inclusion, we think local, internal and the workplace. Why are we having these different conversations to the same discourse? What is the breakdown between these two seemingly different sets of vocabulary?
This interactive 4-hour session will include videos, polling, and breakout sessions. Participants are encouraged to join using a device that has a camera and a microphone as well as a secondary device like a phone or computer that allows for multiple windows to be open at the same time for the polling.
Participants will discuss and reflect on:
The words we use to describe others
Historical perspectives on these two lexicons
Global vs Local
The direction of impact: who is studying who?
At the conclusion of the presentation, participants will have:
A greater recognition of how inclusion and intercultural fit together.
The basic awareness of how we present ourselves in an environment or culture that is not necessarily our own.
Strategies to be more aware of where we are as professionals.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Registration Fees
$20 for Students
$45 for current SIETAR USA members in good standing
$65 for non-members
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Student-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Non-Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Your Seminar Leader
Jay Cafferata, MS, CDE
Mr. Cafferata is a well-known speaker and advocate for issues involving Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging. He considers himself a Social Justice Warrior and has spent decades as an advocate for the Sexual and Gender Minority Community. He has over 20 years of experience working with families of children with special needs. He has a master’s degree in communication studies from University of Nevada, Reno. He holds an associate degree in Deaf Studies from Western Nevada College. Mr. Cafferata is also a Certified Diversity Executive. He can be reached at 
jay@asltraining.com
.
 
 
 
Your Seminar Leader
Jay Cafferata, MS, CDE
Mr. Cafferata is a well-known speaker and advocate for issues involving Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging. He considers himself a Social Justice Warrior and has spent decades as an advocate for the Sexual and Gender Minority Community. He holds an associate degree in Deaf Studies from Western Nevada College. Mr. Cafferata is also a Certified Diversity Executive. He can be reached at 
jay@asltraining.com
.

subject: Meet some of our coaches Hannah
body:
View in browser
 
Opinions and advice from our experts.
 
Change is hard, and the journey to becoming a more diverse, inclusive and equitable organisation is a long one.
 Hannah, go on the journey with people you trust – and like.
One of the secrets to sustainable, tangible behavioural change is working with the right people.
 
When that partnership clicks into place, anything becomes possible. And we’re huge advocates of getting that chemistry right.
 
We wanted to introduce some of our coaches, so you can tell if we’re the right company for you.
 
Beks Hourston
 
Our MD, Head of Women's Leadership. You can read her thoughts on 
the effects of hybrid working on visibility
 and 
a potential confidence crisis in the workplace.
 Or listen to her speak 
about intersectionality
 on our podcast.
 
 
Lucinda Quigley
 
 
Our Head of Working Parents, she’s spoken about 
the menopause
, 
parental anxiety
, and 
the impact of COVID-19 on working parents
. 
 
Or read 
her advice for managers of working parents in this ‘new normal’
.
 
KK Harris
 
Hear KK an Executive Coach Director, speak about 
neurodiversity in the workplace
, and 
chat to our CEO about being white and male in the DEI space
.
 
Rob Bravo
 
 
Rob heads up our Wellbeing programmes – and you can get a glimpse of his wisdom in this article about 
t
he impact of survival mode on decision making,
 or listen to this podcast episode 
about CQ
.
 
They’re just a handful of our coaches - 
If you'd like to meet more of our experts, visit our website 
here
.

subject: Leading Learning in 2023: How the Role of the Chief Learning Officer is Evolving
body:
How the Role of the Chief Learning Officer is Evolving
View this email  in your browser
Join
 Melissa Daimler, CLO at Udemy, and special guest Brenda Sugrue, Global CLO at Ernst and Young, as they delve into the pivotal responsibilities of learning leaders in this era of exponential change.
  
Save your spot
  
Key takeaways:
Stay ahead of the curve: How to keep up and make sense of trends and technologies such as Generative AI.
Shifting from creators to curators: Embracing the transformative shift from being content creators to becoming skilled curators and enablers of skills.
Focus on the fundamentals: Revisit the importance of key principles that continue to drive decisions about learning: business alignment, system thinking, learning science, and the learner experience.

subject: Training Industry Weekly Recap 📅 July 16, 2023
body:
Upcoming Leader Talk, research report sale and more.
View this email in your browser
THE BUSINESS OF LEARNING™
Today’s business landscape is changing — fast. Technologies that may have seemed novel just a few years ago are now par for the course, and advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) continue to make waves across industries.
Training Industry is dedicated to putting out timely resources that can help you deliver impactful training that will position your organization for success in an uncertain future of work.
Register for our upcoming 
Leader Talk
 for tips on upskilling and reskilling and take advantage of our research sale to gain data-backed insights that can help inform your programs.
I also encourage you to check out this week’s featured articles, which cover topics like AI’s impact on inclusion, career pathing and more.
How else can we support your growth and development? Email 
editor@trainingindustry.com
 with your thoughts and ideas.
Sarah Gallo, CPTM
Senior Editor
The World’s Biggest Business Show Arrives in Los Angeles This September!
The Business Show is the leading event for individuals looking to start or grow their dream business. If you’re looking to build connections, learn more about the business world or simply kickstart a new career path, 
The Business Show
 is here to help. Taking place Sept. 20-21, 2023 at the Los Angeles Convention Center, this is the place to be for aspiring entrepreneurs and business-minded individuals. Grab your free ticket now!
Get Your Free Ticket
 
Leader Talk: Upskilling and Reskilling for the Future of Your Workforce
With the shelf life of skills shrinking, organizations must prioritize continuous skills development to ensure employees have the skills they need to be successful in their roles. Learning leaders must work to identify and close skills gaps across the business to effectively upskill and reskill employees for the future of work. Join us July 20 for this complimentary 
Training Industry Leader Talk
 to gain key insights on how to create a continuous learning culture and strategically close skills gaps in your organization.
Reserve Your Spot
 
[Sale] Learning Tech and Services State of the Industry Report Bundle
In today's rapidly changing business landscape, it's crucial for companies to understand and adapt to the ever-evolving market. That's why successful organizations emphasize the importance of research in staying ahead of the curve. To help you gain valuable insights into the learning tech and services markets, we are offering a 50% discount on our 2022 research reports. 
These reports
 cover these sectors’ market sizing, popular subject areas and features, emerging trends and future projections. Don’t miss your chance to save today!
Get the Bundle
 
Training Industry’s New Vendor Directory
With thousands of training vendors across the L&D landscape, choosing the right partner can be a daunting task. Save time by starting your search with the 
Training Industry Vendor Directory

subject: Hannah, remain competitive in an AI world.
body:
Get up to speed on the latest research and intel.  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

HBR STORE
 
 
 
Compete in an AI world
 
Leading economists and business experts predict that AI will completely transform how we live and work. How will AI impact your industry, company, and career? Get up to speed on the latest research and intel with HBR’s 
Artificial Intelligence Library: How to Remain Competitive in an AI World
. 
 
LEARN MORE
 
 
 
This specially priced 7-volume set includes:
 
 
Competing in the Age of AI: Strategy and Leadership When Algorithms and Networks Run the World
 
Packed with examples, many from the most powerful and innovative global AI-driven competitors and based on research in hundreds of firms across many sectors, this is your essential guide for rethinking how your firm competes and operates in the AI era.
 
 
 
 
 
Human + Machine: Reimagining Work in the Age of AI
 
In this much-needed management playbook, you’ll discover how to become an AI-fueled business so you can leap ahead on innovation and profitability.
 
 
 
 
 
Prediction Machines: The Simple Economics of Artificial Intelligence
 
Economists explain the profound impact of AI and how CEOs, managers, policy makers, investors and entrepreneurs can navigate the changes on the horizon.
 
 
 
 
 
HBR’s 10 Must Reads on AI, Analytics, and the New Machine Age
 
Contains the most important HBR articles to help you understand how these technologies work together, how to adopt them, and why your strategy can’t ignore them.
 
 
 
 
 
All-in On AI: How Smart Companies Win Big with Artificial Intelligence
 
Get a rare inside look at what the leading AI adopters are doing, while providing you with the tools to put AI at the core of everything you do.
 
 
 
 
 
Power and Prediction: The Disruptive Economics of Artificial Intelligence
 
When prediction is taken to the max, industries transform, and with such transformation comes disruption. Learn what’s at the root of this and how we can make the coming AI disruption work for us, not against us.
 
 
 
 
 
Artificial Intelligence: Tools for Preparing Your Team for the Future
 
Includes a step-by-step training guide, comprehensive slide deck, case studies, and thought-provoking questions to help stimulate team thinking and kick off the discussions needed to move your company forward.
 
 
Learn what it takes to successfully compete in the AI world. This specially priced 7-item digital library is a must-have for anyone who needs to recognize the potential impact of AI, how it is driving future growth, and how they can compete.

body:

.

convey the value you bring your organization

L&D plan

With only half of 2023 remaining, get started now to learn how you can impress your C-suite with a well-thought-out L&D plan for 2024.
