subject: Sneak Preview: From Day One's 2024 Live & Virtual Schedule
body:
Corporate-values conference series and media outlet From Day One has set an ambitious schedule of events for 2024
 
 
FROM DAY ONE
Announces 2024 Slate of Corporate Values Conferences,
In Person and Virtual 
Top executives in HR, Benefits, Diversity, Corporate Culture, Employee Engagement, and Corporate Responsibility discuss employee engagement, belonging, 
inclusive benefits, hybrid work, well-being, and more
JULY 13, 2023
 –
 From Day One
, the conference series focused on innovative ways for companies to foster stronger relationships with workers and communities, is announcing its 2024 schedule of in-person and virtual events. 
The company will host more than 35 conferences, including single-day events in cities across the U.S. – the most From Day One has ever held in one year – and a full slate of half-day virtual events.
"We're feeling the aftershocks of the three great workplace upheavals of the decade so far: the pandemic, the racial-justice movement, and the Great Resignation," said Stephen Koepp, From Day One's chief content officer. "While the pandemic has passed, the return-to-office migration is a contentious journey. The hoped-for progress toward diversity, equity, and inclusion has prompted a backlash. And workers are mostly done quitting en masse, but their expectations about job satisfaction have only grown. On top of these issues, the arrival of generative AI is going to change virtually everyone's job. Company leaders will need to face fresh challenges, and From Day One's conferences in 2024 will be bringing them the latest ideas about these developing stories."
Whether in person or online, From Day One’s accredited events bring together top executives and decision makers in HR, benefits, diversity, corporate culture, employee engagement, and corporate responsibility to discuss timely themes like hybrid work, employee benefits, diversity and inclusion, social impact, and employee well-being. 
From Day One is recognized as the pre-eminent forum for corporate-values discussions. The company’s in-person events break the typical conference mold by presenting in inspiring spaces, including art museums, opera houses, and centers of community gathering. From Day One was among the first to convene executives to address subjects like balancing productivity with well-being, developing diversity in leadership, supporting working parents, hybrid work, and offering better career paths, and the firm expects further evolution in the ways businesses and society will interact next year.
Even as the company looks ahead to 2024, this year still has several From Day One conferences remaining in 2023. The company will travel to 
Boston
 on Sept. 12, 
Manhattan
 on Sept. 26, 
Philadelphia
 on Oct. 3, 
Denver
 on Oct. 18, 
Los Angeles
 on Nov. 2, and 
Miami
 on Nov. 14. From Day One also holds virtual events and webinars every week; find the schedule of upcoming events at
 fromdayone.co
.
The full slate of 2024 in-person and virtual dates is below. In-person dates are preliminary and subject to change. Speakers and participants will be announced in the months leading up to the events. All From Day One conferences are eligible for SHRM and HRCI credits.
 
 
FROM DAY ONE 2024 IN-PERSON CONFERENCE SCHEDULE
 
*ATLANTA, GA — January 24
*HOUSTON, TX — February 6
*SEATTLE, WA — February 20
*SILICON VALLEY, CA — February 27
SALT LAKE CITY, UT — March 12
*WASHINGTON, D.C. — March 26
BROOKLYN, NY — April 9
BOSTON, MA — April 18
CHICAGO, IL — April 21  
DALLAS, TX — May 7
*MINNEAPOLIS, MN — May 14
AUSTIN, TX — June 6
SAN FRANCISCO, CA — June 26
BOSTON, MA — September 12
NASHVILLE, TN — October 1
PHILADELPHIA, PA — October 8 
MANHATTAN, NY — October 22
DENVER, CO — October 29
LOS ANGELES, CA — November 12
MIAMI, FL — November 26
SAN FRANCISCO, CA — December 3
* indicates exact date is confirmed.
  
FROM DAY ONE 2024 VIRTUAL CONFERENCE SCHEDULE
Jan. 10, 2024
A Fresh Commitment to a Culture of Well-Being 
While many employers recognize the connection between well-being and productivity, creating a healthy balance in the real world of work can be challenging. What are the key choices and thoughtful compromises that must be made for workers to thrive as well as produce? How can managers be trained to make the well-being of their workers a top priority? How can companies get a better sense of which benefits and rewards are most effective–and encourage workers to take advantage of them?
Feb. 14, 2024
Getting to the Next Stage of Diversity and Belonging 
At a time of resistance and corporate austerity, DEI advocates will need to re-energize themselves and their organizations with new ideas, programs, and reasoning for the cause of diversity. What can DEI practitioners learn from companies with consistent success? How are companies changing their policies to respond to court rulings and lawsuits? What practices have brought the most progress in bringing diversity to leadership ranks?
March 6, 2024
Employee Engagement: Tapping the Secrets of Energizing Workers 
Companies want their employees to be enthused and involved, yet employers need to be thoughtful in fostering these qualities in authentic ways. What’s the latest thinking about how employers can understand the motivations of their workers–and how to respond? What are the best methods for recognizing achievement, both individually and among teams? What’s the connection between engagement and job satisfaction? In the hybrid work environment, what binds workers together and wards off anxiety and loneliness? 
April 3, 2024
Benefits that Fit Individual Needs Without Busting the Budget
Having made a commitment to recognize the unique needs of individuals, the secret is in the execution. What are the emerging benefits and rewards that workers are seeking, from fertility care to financial wellness? How can companies use technology to stay in close touch with what individuals are experiencing–and where they need help as a result? How can companies choose among myriad point solutions and innovative new platforms? What are the most cost-effective rewards in terms of investments and outcomes?
May 22, 2024
The Art and Science of Employee Retention, Coaching and Advancement
While the pace of job-hopping has eased, employers have a powerful motivation to retain skilled workers, both for financial and cultural reasons. How can employers use new tools, including AI, to gain insights about what’s inspiring their workers to stay committed–or walk out the door? Since attrition is often caused by poor relationships with managers, what are innovative ways for employers to train their workers to be better leaders at a time when workers have higher expectations for job satisfaction? How can technology help make coaching more effective?
June 12, 2024
Bringing Talent Acquisition into the Digital Age 
Despite layoffs making headlines now, all the demographic and digital trends point toward tough competition for workers in the future–maybe sooner than most expect. What are the new techniques and tools that talent-acquisition can use to envision the workforce their company will need in the future? What data and insights can HR and TA leaders provide to the company to be ahead of trends? How can companies do a better job of internal recruiting and promoting internal mobility? What are the best practices for hiring based on skills and potential, rather than credentials?
July 10, 2024
Learning and Development: How New Tools Are Changing Upskilling and Career Mobility 
As employers put more emphasis on skills as the currency for worker development, they’re seeking new ways to measure them, fill in gaps, and predict the skills needed in the future. How can these new tools, including AI, create better matches between employees and projects? How can employers gain insights from the data they gather? Why do real-world simulations help measure certain skills better than traditional assessments? 
July 17, 2024
Innovative Benefits That Support Healthy Families and Caregivers
As the pandemic’s caregiving crisis showed, employers found significant gaps in their support for the parents and other caregivers in their workforces. The resulting scramble to help has produced a wealth of new HR policies, benefit offerings, and management practices. Where is the greatest demand for support, as well as the most innovative new methods? What have been the most cost-effective ways to help caregivers of all kinds, including parents as well as “sandwich generation” workers caring for elderly and disabled relatives? 
Aug. 7, 2024
Employee Engagement: Using Technology to Gain Insight Into Work Needs and Ambitions 
Traditional methods like town-hall meetings and surveys can be effective, but data and well-drawn insights can give top leaders a heads up about evolving patterns and trends in their workforces. How can AI and other technology be deployed in a way that brings new insights yet still respects privacy and the individual human factors at play? What approaches will bring employers new empathy for worker needs, ambitions, and well-being? 
Aug. 28, 2024
Pursuing Higher Productivity With Human Factors in Mind
In a competitive and uncertain climate, most companies need to do more with less. Yet if workers are their greatest asset, employers need to make sure the push for greater output is sustainable. What is the latest thinking about how to measure productivity, the means for stimulating it, and ensuring that workers have the energy to meet their goals–as well as thrive over the long run?
 
Sept. 18, 2024
Building a Corporate Culture That Workers Can Understand, Influence and Embrace 
 
Company culture is amorphous yet vital–the shared beliefs, values, traditions and behaviors that drive the actions of individuals and the organization as a whole. Who should be the architects of a company’s culture and how should it be designed and constructed? How should the culture be communicated, broadly and in everyday actions? How should a company start out on a project to evolve its culture in a credible way?  
Oct. 16, 2024
Modernizing Your Workplace for a More Flexible, Inclusive Era
The arrival of hybrid work sent virtually every employer back to the drawing board about what the workplace should look like, including floor plans, digital platforms, meetings, and even office furniture. After more than three years of experimenting, what have innovative companies discovered about what works–and what doesn’t? How have they improved workplace environments to be healthier, as well as more productive? How have these changes affected the goals of diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging?
Nov. 20, 2024
Finding and Deploying HR Tech That Will Empower Workers 
 
The blossoming of innovation in HR technology has given employers untold new abilities to organize, inspire, develop, reward, and care for their workers. Yet this revolution presents new challenges for companies in choosing and supervising these tech tools. How should these tech platforms be evaluated? Which departments of the company should take responsibility–and how can organizations coordinate these moves? How can companies make sure they’re empowering their workers rather than overloading them with adaptation and distraction?
Dec. 11, 2024
Pioneering Approaches to Digital Transformation and the Future of Work
The emergence of generative AI in 2023 marked the arrival of a transforming technology that will change human roles, add and subtract jobs, and create astounding new capabilities. How can companies manage the transition, both from the short-term competitive pressures to  long-term corporate survival? How can AI be used to unleash creativity? Where are the areas for abuse, intentional or otherwise? How will digital transformation affect fields from talent acquisition to learning and development? 
 
ABOUT FROM DAY ONE
From Day One is a conference series and media outlet focused on innovative ways for companies to foster stronger relationships with their employees, customers, and communities. At a time when society holds businesses to a rising level of accountability, From Day One explores how companies can build well-grounded values into their business—diversity, responsibility, transparency—and stick with them in an economy driven by disruption.
What’s unique about From Day One is its cross-disciplinary approach, bringing together executives from the fields of corporate social responsibility, human resources, marketing, and communications. Its events facilitate people-focused conversations that promote real, actionable ideas for and from executives, civic-leaders, authors, and journalists across the country. Businesses have increasingly seen the wisdom of putting people first. From Day One’s mission is to help companies find the best ways to deliver on that promise, from day one.

subject: Work smarter, network harder at Sales Comp’23
body:
Register now for THE event of the year for sales-comp pros
 
Strategize and Socialize at Sales Comp’23!
 
 
 
Don’t
 miss your chance to join forces with other movers and shakers in the tight-knit sales
-
compensation community this August 21-23 in Chicago! Sales Comp’23 has it all—a program packed with tips
, 
trends
 
and tactics to motivate high-performing sales teams and loyal customers 
PLUS 
ample opportunities
 to network with other top sales-comp leaders and providers.
 
 
 
Claim My Spot 
It’s Summertime and These Topics Are Hot!
 
 
 
Whether 
you’re
 focused on sales compensation, sales 
operations
 or sales analytics, 
you’ll
 get up-to-the-minute information and resources to drive sales success in challenging times, with solutions-focused sessions like …
 
 
 
Consumption-Based Pricing: Think Tank Solutions to a Serious Sales Comp Puzzle!
 
Consumption-based pricing allows customers to pay only for what they use—which can pose challenges when it comes to figuring out sales compensation. You can’t discern what was “sold” until usage scales—or doesn’t. So how do you decide when salespeople get paid, and for what? In this interactive session, two experts share their perspectives and engage the audience to uncover new paths forward. Join the conversation and leave invigorated with innovative ideas!
 
Speakers: 
 
 
 
Donya Rose, The Cygnal Group
 
 
 
Rick Butler, ServiceNow
 
 
 
More Than Pretty Pictures: Drive Impact through Data Visualization
 
You've got the software. You’ve got the sales analytics. You’ve even got some snazzy visuals. But you may be missing one critical thing: impact! Too often, our data analysis fails to adequately convey a problem or highlight a solution. It’s time to put your data to work for you! Don’t miss this practical session, where you’ll learn how to create data visualizations that drive decision-making and elevate outcomes for optimal impact.
 
Speakers:
 
 
 
Paul Reiman, Novo Insights
 
 
 
Bryan Briscoe, Marriott International, Inc.
 
 
 
 
Join u
s
 to drive your best-ever sales results through smart 
sales-
comp strategies like these
—and many more
!

subject: 🎙️ Decoded: New Podcast Release
body:
Join us in unpacking the phrase "But you don't look autistic" with Becca Lory Hector from Truly Inclusive Leadership.
 
New Episode Release
Recording & Transcript
 
"But you don't look autistic."
The phrase “but you don’t look autistic” presupposes autism as an “other,” ostracizing autistic people from the conversation and discounting the community’s diverse lived experiences. So how do we respond to anti-autistic microaggressions, and what can we do to foster a sense of belonging through inclusive language?
 
To help us unpack this loaded question, 
Brave Conversations with LCW
 Host Larry Baker (he/him) is joined by Lead Consultant and Founder of Truly Inclusive Leadership Becca Lory Hector (she/her), who shares her lived experience as an openly Autistic Professional on a mission to close the disability gap in leadership.
Featuring:
 
 
Becca Lory Hector
Lead Consultant and Founder
Truly Inclusive Leadership

body:
Join Us for DI-NC's Celebration of the 33rd Anniversary of the Passage of ADA
 
 
Monthly
 
Special Event
 
Register Today for the 2023 ADA Celebration
Register Now!
Join Us on July 26th at 11:00 AM for
"Champions of the ADA in North Carolina"
 
 
 
 
 
Please join us for 
Disability:IN North Carolina's “Champions of the ADA in North Carolina” event on July 26, 2023, at 11:00 AM!
 As an organization dedicated to promoting employment opportunities for people with disabilities in the corporate business field, DI-NC seeks to educate businesses about the benefits of hiring candidates with disabilities. This event will enable participants to gain new insights into what the ADA means to people with disabilities in North Carolina and how North Carolinians played a role as early champions of the ADA.
 
North Carolina ADA Champions featured include:
Mayia Warren, Self Advocate, Artist, Musician
Thomas Colclough, EEOC, Director of Field Management Programs for EEOC
Robert Rusch, Director, PWC
Holly Riddle, M.Ed., J. D., Assistant Director for Olmstead Plan Implementation, Office of Senior Advisor, ADA, NCDHHS
DI-NC
 is pleased to share that our ADA Video was edited by 
Scott Graham of OptiMystic Video.
 
Scott has been a videographer in Charlotte, North Carolina, for over 18 years, working for clients such as Club Med Resorts, the City of Charlotte, Paramedics for Children and Freedom School Partners. With over 10 years of experience Production Sound for Feature Films, TV series, TV commercials, short films, web series, and corporate videos. Scott has worked on films such as “Are You There, God, it’s me Margaret”, “The Supremes at Big Earl’s All You Can Eat”, and shows such as “The Peripheral”. He also has experience with Post Production Sound and is a musician.

subject: Building our DEI Comms strategy on rock
body:
Finding your place in the culture conversation ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
Hi 
Hannah.
 
How's your July going? It's been non-stop on the DEI front and I hope you've been able to get a break and rest. After the recent US Supreme Court decisions, we need some ice on our forehead from the headaches, pain and chaos it's creating. 
In the absence of clarity, we have chaos
 
When we have chaos we have dissonance. When we have dissonance we trigger worry, anxiety, and stress. That puts the brakes on progress. It then puts people up against each other rather than bringing people together. This is where we step up as DEI communicators. 
It's a time to lean on what we have committed to and show up. You can see the posts I made on Affirmative Action about organizations 
saying something
 and what it sets in motion for 
future talent
.
Three years ago this summer, many of us were out in the streets
 
Summer 2020 was my impetus to write 
The Conscious Communicator. 
My clients will say that they've done a lot of good and they believed they were doing the right thing and that's valid. 
However, our commitments were built on sand, blown over by the whiff of a storm or pushback. We're seeing where our strategies aren't strong, have holes, or are too shallow.
To be fair, we often don't understand the depth of a commitment until we're in the midst of trying to keep it
This is frickin' hard work. A lot of variables and personalities. 
We've seen the surge of wanting to talk about societal issues and now we're seeing the rolling back, the shielding and folding. It's time to do something different. 
We know better. 
We know we need DEPTH. 
Tailored is the bridge to hesitant leaders
This month's Book Club and Community meet up is focusing on the chapter, "T is for Tailored". It's the bridge to engage leaders, HR and Legal.
Our organization doesn't have to do "all the things" externally. However, we do have to do our part and collectively we'll get the work done. 
Tailored is about having that strategic conversation that ties our core capabilities to what our "lane" is in the work. It is the catalyst for proactive positioning us authentically and meaningfully on social topics. 
Amazing work comes from this alignment. It relieves pressure and builds trust with employees and customers while protecting brand reputation. 
It helps with feeling stuck between "you're not doing enough" and "you're doing too much", which makes some organizations end up not doing anything...and friends, that's not an option (
read Edelman's Trust Barometer)
.
Let's build our strategy on rock
We have to be strategic and intentional and there's a method to do just that: The DEPTH Model. 
Set up some time with me
 and I'll walk you through the process. 
Together, we can lower defenses, get the conversation going, have it be productive, and get us to a position where we can stand and withstand because, simply, employees and customers expect it. 
Skoden (let's go then!)
kim
PS: I also made a post on 
Freedom and the 4th of July
 set in the context of how I celebrated as a kid and having no idea what this holiday meant for my grandmother, the matriarch of our Muscogee Nation lineage. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This podcast is 
made just for you. 
 
Communicate Like You Give a Damn is a new weekly podcast where we explore the communicator's role and responsibility in Diversity, Equity and Inclusion (DEI) work. Guests include DEI strategists, Chief Comms Officers, DEI practitioners, inclusive designers and research-based authors on empowering differences. New episode every Tuesday.
Listen, Subscribe, Share Now

category

subject: [Infographic] 3 Ways Training Can Improve the Employee Experience
body:
Happy employees are loyal employees. Find out how training can boost engagement and retention.
View this email  in your browser
Study after study indicates that employees who don’t have opportunities to learn and grow in their organization are more likely to be disengaged, disconnected and looking for better prospects elsewhere.
Learning and development (L&D) has the power to improve employees’ experience throughout their career journey. Offering opportunities for growth, collaboration and connection through training can keep employees engaged, increase job satisfaction and improve retention.
This infographic
 offers three ways to enhance the employee experience through training. Download now for tips on how training can boost engagement and retention: Because happy employees are loyal employees.
Get the Infographic
Find more solutions relevant to your challenges as a training professional. Training Industry's monthly infographics focus on trending topics central to effective learning and development.

subject: From Day One: The Diversity Backlash Is Here
body:
The backlash against diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) is in full swing. DEI programs are now a campaign issue, with more legislatures seeking to ban DEI efforts altogether. Boycotts have shaken brands. 
Corporate DEI budgets have been cut
, while surveys show a rising tide of “diversity fatigue.” DEI leaders, once given a mandate to help companies “do better,” have grown dispirited. 
 
The 
Supreme Court’s 6-3 decision
 on June 27, striking down affirmative action in higher education, was widely anticipated by the business community. A friend-of-the court brief was filed by dozens of technology, finance, and health care companies who support DEI. Ranging from 
American Express to Walgreens
, companies pleaded with the court that they rely on “racially and ethnic diverse student bodies” to find talent. 
 
We've secured an exclusive opportunity for our members to take part 
in AARP's Employee Caregiver Program Series. This series, free of charge for From Day One subscribers, is an easy way to make your workplace more caregiver-inclusive via live virtual programs on a range of challenges that working family caregivers face at home and work. To learn more and reserve a spot, visit 
 
https://caregiving.fromdayone.co/
.
 
There will be workplace ramifications, even though the case applied to higher education. Questions arose in many workplaces: Will DEI programs now be weakened or banned? Can race be considered in employment decisions? Will an activist Supreme Court look for a case in which to extend its educational dictates to the workplace?
 
Legal and HR experts advise DEI advocates to be proactive. Here are five steps you can take, as reported by From Day One contributor Andrea Sachs:
 
Remind Stakeholders Why DEI Is Beneficial
 
DEI is both morally right and beneficial to the bottom line. “Study after study demonstrates that, across organizations, diversity enhances 
critical thinking, creativity and collaboration
, as well as productivity, profitability and 
performance
,” 
wrote Ford Foundation CEO Darren Walker
 in the 
New York Times
. 
 
Make Sure Your DEI Programs Aren’t in Conflict With Current Laws
 
Review your employee handbook, DEI framework, and other written policies with legal and employment-law experts. “Be sure your policies and programs don’t unintentionally run afoul of anti-discrimination laws. Quotas and preferences–as well as perceived unfairness–can create legal problems,” 
advises the Fisher Phillips law firm
. 
 
NYU legal experts Kenji Yoshino and David Glasgow, 
authors of a book
 on how to talk about DEI, 
offer instructions
 for a “self-audit” to avoid legal exposure. They suggest sorting programs as red (high risk), yellow (medium risk), and green (low risk). But they discourage knee-jerk changes: “Companies are still allowed to strive for a diverse workforce.” 
 
Take Steps to Avoid the Possibility of a Reverse Discrimination Lawsuit
 
Corporate DEI programs surged
 after the murder of George Floyd. The result has been a legal backlash by right-wing activists and legislators, and that trend is expected to intensify. America First Legal, headed by former Donald Trump adviser Stephen Miller, has filed complaints with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, asking it to investigate diversity and hiring practices at companies like McDonald’s and Unilever. In June, a jury in New Jersey ordered Starbucks to pay a white former manager $25.6 million, finding she had been fired because of reverse discrimination.
 
Although reverse-discrimination claims are not new, the risk of incurring them may be increased. Employers should research state legislation restricting DEI initiatives, as in Florida and Texas. But Alvin B. Tillery, Jr., director of the Center for Study of Diversity and Democracy, cautions against overreacting.
 Tillery told the 
New York Times
, “I do worry about corporate counsels who see their main job as keeping organizations from getting sued—I do worry about hyper-compliance.”
 
Explore New Ways of Growing Your Candidate Pool
 
Businesses
 depend on higher education
 to provide diverse candidates. That flow will be stanched by the court’s decision. “I don’t believe that there’s a dispute that university demographics will become more homogenous,” said Janine Yancey, founder and CEO of
 Emtrain
, an inclusion-and-belonging consultancy. This will lead to “a smaller talent pipeline,” she told From Day One. 
 
It has
 occurred already
 in the nine states that have banned race-conscious affirmative action. After California voters enacted a ban on affirmative action in 1996, the number of Black students at the University of California campuses in Berkeley and Los Angeles plummeted. Since Michigan ended affirmative action in 2006, the number of Black students at the University of Michigan has dropped dramatically.
 
Employers will need to cast a wider net for a diverse workforce. Rhonda V. Sharpe, founder and president of the
 Women’s Institute for Science, Equity, and Race
, sees a silver lining. Said Sharpe, “I will not shed a tear for affirmative action but will rejoice in the possibilities for Historically Black Colleges and Hispanic Serving Institutions.”  
 
The impact of affirmative action was mostly in elite universities. “The majority of Black and Hispanic students attend universities that accept more than three-quarters of their applicants,”
 wrote academics Richard Arum and Mitchell L. Stevens in the 
New York Times
.
 “The current opportunity to bring equity to American higher education lies in a collective re-commitment to the quality and success of more accessible institutions.” Experts recommend HR leaders look even further upstream, investing in programs to develop underserved youth earlier in life.
 
Put More Stress on Employee Retention
 
With a less diverse candidate pool, retaining a representative workforce could become difficult. “No one wants to work in an environment where they are ‘the only,’” Janice Gassam Asure, founder of BWG Business Solutions, a consultancy that helps organizations create inclusive environments, wrote in 
Forbes
. She warns the decision “will not only make it more challenging to retain the employees you already have, but it will likely be more difficult to attract new talent from underrepresented communities.”
 
It is important right now to consider employee sentiment. Y-Vonne Hutchinson, CEO of DEI consulting and strategy firm 
ReadySet
, asserts: “Your employees, particularly those from historically marginalized backgrounds, may be experiencing anxiety, stress, sadness, fear, and disappointment right now.” Hutchinson urges companies to provide support in the form of employment resource groups and mental health resources.
 
Stalwarts like Iesha Berry, chief diversity and engagement officer and head of people experience at DocuSign, have no intention of giving in to right-wing pressure. “It doesn’t change our focus,” 
she told the 
Wall Street Journal
. Diversity is “not a stand-alone, and it’s not something that is the flavor of the day, but critically important to the business and the business success.” 
Read the full story here
.
  
WEBINAR RECAP
  
Equitable Rewards: Do you have Pride in Your Benefits? 
A good benefits package ranks among the top three most important factors for job satisfaction, according to a 
survey
 from the Society for Human Resource Management. But the usual benefits plans aren’t keeping up with what employees want and need. Your existing employees may be shopping around for packages that better suit their needs, said Corrinne Hobbs, VP of business development at 
Ovia Health
, a family health benefits platform. “We learned that 91% of our members would consider a lateral move to a place with better family benefits and a family friendly culture,” Hobbs said. For BIPOC and LGBTQ+ employees, inclusive benefits can encourage well-being, team retention, and a more diverse workforce. 
Read the full story here
. 
  
LIVE CONFERENCE HIGHLIGHTS
  
Why Career Growth Is a Mutual Benefit for Both Workers and Employers: 
According to Pew Research, 63% of people who left jobs in 2021 cited
 a lack of advancement opportunities
. “We spend a lot of time and energy focusing on what an employee really wants,” said Joji Gill, VP of HR
 at Applied Materials
. “We realized, as our demographics have changed, that we actually did not understand.” Gill’s team learned to enable supervisors as coaches. “An employee really owns their careers, but we facilitate it through their managers and through the opportunities we provide," Gill said, speaking to a panel of HR leaders moderated by Dan Ashley of 
ABC7 KGO-TV Bay Area
 at From Day One’s
 San Francisco conference
. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
How to Give Workers the Resources and Opportunities They Need to Thrive: 
At a time of uncertainty and rapid change, the keys to a happy workplace are flexibility and intentionality. So says Jessica Swank, chief people officer for
 Box, Inc.
, a Silicon Valley cloud content-management company that is consistently rated a “
Great Place to Work
.” Like most tech companies prior to the pandemic, Box operated largely in person. Now, after many iterations of working remotely, employees have embraced a hybrid approach. Swank spoke with Erin Griffith, a 
New York Times 
reporter, in a fireside chat at From Day One’s
 San Francisco
 conference. As arrangements sort themselves out post-pandemic, employee preferences vary widely. Some workers may want to return to the office for in-person mentorship. Others who are caretakers of children or elderly parents, or both, have contrasting needs. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
Beyond Group Benefits: Supporting the Employee’s Whole Self at Work: 
Three weeks after Israel Gutierrez joined 
Axios
 in 2022 as vice president of talent acquisition, his brother passed away. Along with the emotional toll, funeral costs were outrageous. Fortunately, Axios had implemented an Axios Family Fund in response to Covid, investing $100,000 for employees in need. As a new hire, Gutierrez was reluctant to apply. His boss said, “Just do it.” Axios made accessing funds easy, fast, and confidential with only three people in the loop. At the June 
From Day One conference in Austin,
 a panel moderated by 
Austin Business Journal’s
 Sahar Chmais discussed how supporting the whole individual at work is about so much more than offering generous benefits. 
Read the full story here
. 
  
VIRTUAL EVENT HIGHLIGHTS
  
Fostering an Inclusive Work Environment: Embracing Diversity in Every Form: 
Diversity is not limited to identities that are visible upon first meeting someone. Kristen Carlisle, VP and general manager at 
Betterment
, has been living with an auto-immune condition for ten years. Dave Wilkin, founder of 
10kc.com
, grew up a gay, STEM-loving kid in a small town who would never have gone to college without a scholarship. Timothy Fair, VP of DEI at 
Burlington
, is proud of his religious identity: “I am deeply guided by an identity that’s usually invisible,” he told journalist Lydia Dishman in a panel at 
From Day One’s June virtual conference
 about how we think about DEI. “Those principles have really guided the way I see the world and how the world sees me,” said Fair. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
The Zigzag Career: Why This Microsoft Executive Is a Believer in Reskilling. 
As technology charges forward, reskilling and upskilling have emerged as alternatives for closing talent gaps. Upskilling programs can help top performers discover what lights them up, increasing retention and engagement. For one executive, pursuing new opportunities led to a rewarding career. “I'm a believer in what I call the ‘zigzag career’ and shifting around,” said Carlos Pardo, chief learning officer at 
Microsoft 
Latin America. After starting with Microsoft as an intern, Pardo worked in finance, operations, marketing, and sales before landing his current position. These moves and opportunities for coaching and upskilling were vital, he said in a fireside chat at the June conference. 
Read the full story here
.  
 
Engaging an Increasingly Diverse Early-Career Workforce: 
Young people entering the workforce are unafraid to ask for things their predecessors shied away from. Generation Z applicants typically pose blunt questions when evaluating an employer, said Dexter Davis, VP of HR and DEI at 
Ecolab
. “It’s specifically, ‘What are the things you’re doing? How are you ensuring equity?’ And how soon can they be part of the organization and have a voice?’” At the June conference,
 
a panel of five talent acquisition and DEI leaders—Davis among them—spoke about the ways employers are attracting and keeping young workers. 
Read the full story here
. 
  
QUICK HITS
  
What Climate Changes Has to Do With the Looming UPS Union Strike: 
Across the U.S., according to 
Time
, UPS drivers are braving one of the most immediate aspects of
 climate change
: longer, more intense heat waves that make long hours in wheeled ovens not just uncomfortable but dangerous. On June 25, 2022, Esteban Chavez, 24,
 died of suspected heat stroke
 delivering packages in Pasadena, on a day with temperatures in the high 90s. Weeks later, a driver
 collapsed on a customer’s doorstep
 in Arizona when the temperature hit 110°F. More than 143 UPS employees have been hospitalized for heat injuries between 2015 and 2022, according to
 company records
. Still, UPS refused to air-condition their familiar dark brown trucks. On June 16, UPS’s 340,000 Teamsters union members voted to strike starting August 1, unless demands for improved working conditions, including air-conditioned vehicles and ice for coolers at cargo centers, were included in a five-year contract. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
Americans Have Quit Quitting Their Jobs: 
The surge in Americans quitting their jobs has abated–a trend 
The Wall Street Journal 
considers a sign that the labor market is cooling from ultra-hot levels as the Federal Reserve raises interest rates. Americans voluntarily left 4 million jobs in May, the Labor Department said. That marked a drop of around 500,000 from 4.5 million in November 2021, the highest level in Labor Department records back to 2000. The so-called quits rate—the number of resignations as a share of total employment— averaged 2.5% from March to May, down from 3% as recently as April 2022, and only slightly higher than the pre-pandemic level. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
The Boomers Are Retiring: See Why That’s Bad News for Workers: 
Ranks of retirees are growing much faster today than the number of new workers, ushering in an unprecedented graying of America that will reshape our workforce and economy. For 50 years, boomers, born between 1946 and 1964, have worked through the American labor force like a big meal inside an anaconda. As they age, the workforce is becoming older than ever. As they retire, they’ll push the worker-to-retiree ratio lower than ever. Lower numbers of workers per retiree threaten programs like Social Security and Medicare, which support older Americans by taxing workers. As the share of working Americans shrinks, that money will, too. Both programs 
face funding shortfalls
 in the next decade without higher taxes or cuts to benefits, the 
Washington Post 
reported. 
Read the full story here
. 
  
SPONSOR SPOTLIGHTS
  
STORK CLUB
 
How Employers Are Making Family-Building Benefits More Inclusive: 
Now that employers are more cognizant of the myriad ways families can operate, they’re removing barriers to reproductive health and family-building benefits. An example: “Historically speaking, women would require a diagnosis of infertility to receive access to artificial insemination in vitro fertilization,” said Serafina Miller, senior principal consultant with the 
health practice at Mercer
. But this is changing, Miller said. In the webinar “Why Family-Building Benefits Are a Critical Business Need,” Miller spoke with Liz Pittinger, head of global customer success at family-health benefits provider
 Stork Club
, about popular and innovative additions to health care packages that support the needs of diverse workforces. 
Read the full story here
.
 
THINKHUMAN
 
Inclusive Leadership Development for People Leaders at Your Organization: 
American businesses are spending more than 
$8 billion per year
 to combat bias and expand diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging. The bad news, according to leadership consultancy 
ThinkHuman
 founder and CEO Meredith Haberfeld, is that many well-intentioned initiatives can prove counterproductive. “In a meta-analysis of more than 490 studies involving some 80,000 people, the psychologist 
Patrick Forscher
 and his colleagues found that unconscious bias training did not change behavior,” said Haberfeld. So how can businesses build an effective and efficient program that truly improves diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging? Haberfeld shared insights in a talk at 
From Day One’s June virtual conference
. 
Read the full story here
.
WORKTANGO
 
The Evolution of Employee Recognition and Rewards: Trends and Best Practices. 
Longevity isn’t an accurate or productive measurement of true employee engagement. In fact, “94% of organizations have employee recognition and rewards programs, yet only one-third of those are effective,” according to Merrily McGugan the VP of brand and communications at 
WorkTango
. What does it mean to have an effective rewards and recognition program? We all work harder when we know we’re appreciated, morale is also better and people tend to stay longer. “Companies that excel at employee recognition are 12x more likely to generate strong business results than their peers who are not doing it,” said McGugan during her talk at 
From Day One’s Austin conference
. What are some best practices companies can easily implement? McGugan offers seven ideas. 
Read the full story here
.
THE FELLOWSHIP
The Making of a Master Builder of a Strong Company Culture: 
A company’s culture can be challenging to define, let alone build. Kelly Ann Doherty, chief administrative officer of the home-loan provider
 Mr. Cooper Group
, takes an architectural approach that has helped earn the company a reputation as a
 Great Place to Work
. Doherty’s own trajectory is a case study on how a leader can learn to successfully communicate the beliefs and behaviors that guide the actions of individuals as well as the company as a whole. Doherty traces her growing mastery to her attendance in 2018 at
 The Fellowship
, a four-day master class in organizational culture for HR leaders in Santa Fe, N.M. Doherty was always passionate about building her career around people, and knew that communicating culture was part of her role as Mr. Cooper Group’s chief communications officer. However, it wasn’t until she attended The Fellowship that she saw what a career in building culture could look like. 
Read the full story here
.
AARP
Finding Purpose: What Older Workers Say They Want in a Job: 
The number of older workers 
is growing
, prompting a closer look at what job characteristics are important to members of this experienced talent pool. Over the next decade, three in 10 Americans ages 65 to 74 are projected to be in the workforce, up from 26% of that age group in 2021, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. “Gains in longevity mean that our younger workers are looking at extended careers, and that the five-generation workforce is likely going to be the norm moving forward,” Heather Tinsley-Fix, a senior advisor for financial resilience at 
AARP
, said in a presentation at From Day One’s June virtual conference. To learn more about the employment concerns and priorities of an older demographic, 
AARP conducted a study
 of 2,000 U.S. workers ages 40 and up. 
Read the full story here
.
  
  
UPCOMING EVENTS
  
WEBINARS
 
Get credit! From Day One is accredited by the professional organizations SHRM and HRCI, and most of our sessions qualify for professional development credit from both organizations. See our individual event-registration pages for credit details. 
 
Aug. 3: How the Definition of Total Rewards Is Changing. 
The broadening scope of rewards is helping employers respond to more diverse needs, as well as giving employers the ability to focus on rewards that provide the biggest impact. What are the newest and most effective rewards, ranging from relocation programs and scholarships to management development and employee recognition? How can companies evaluate these diverse programs in a way that has emotional impact but represent efficient business practices? 
Register now
.
 
Aug. 8: Filling the Gaps in Your Healthcare Benefits to Make Them More Inclusive. 
To provide personalized medical-benefit plans for an increasingly diverse workforce, employers need to find the shortcomings in their offerings and explore innovative ways to fix them. Workers today have higher expectations when it comes to employer support for family-building, wellness, and mental health. What kind of surveys and other tools can companies use to assess the needs of their workforce? In a marketplace with many point solutions, how can employers find the right mix for their workers? From the point of view of the employees, what are the most inclusive ways to help them navigate the complex healthcare system? 
Register now
.
Aug. 15: Mind Over Money: Boosting Employee Mental Health by Reducing Their Financial Stress. 
The connection is dramatic: nearly 86% of employees say that their personal finances are one of the top stressors in their lives, harming their mental health and happiness. Yet there's a remedy: the vast majority of workers who enrolled in an employer-based financial wellness program say their financial stress was reduced. What are the most effective elements of a financial wellness program? How does it lead to better financial decision-making? Is it cost-effective for employers, and can it lead to better health outcomes for workers? 
Register now
.
 
Aug. 17: When Belonging Is Broken: How an Intervention Can Strengthen Your Organization’s Culture. 
When a company has a healthy culture of belonging, it reaps many benefits: high performance, highly engaged employees, psychological safety, and the freedom to be authentic. But many organizations drift into the opposite condition. They suffer from ineffective practices for diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI). One of the symptoms is inadvertently excluding some in an attempt to include others. How can companies recognize when they need an intervention? What steps should they take to reverse the syndrome–and who should manage the process? What will it look like when they embed belonging at the team and organizational level? 
Register now
.  
 
Sept. 19: Ageism in Industries. 
Ageism remains the open secret in the advertising, marketing, and branding categories. Subtle discrimination is vaguely disguised in commercials and employer branding, especially in the beauty and tech industries. Often the About Us and Meet our Team landing pages can tell you more about a brand than the nicely polished imagery. If you’re an organization that struggles to attract and retain experienced talent, join AARP Senior Advisor Heather Tinsley-Fix and New & Improved Principal Lisa Balser for a discussion on how ageism shows up in marketing and how employers can signal and implement a more inclusive culture. They’ll cover age discrimination trends and how they adversely affect an organization’s strategic goals; the silent signals of ageism in your organization, from client-facing work to internal workflows and decisions; and strategies to become more age-inclusive, not just in your marketing strategy but in creating teams. 
Register now
. 
 
Oct. 10: Why Women’s Health Benefits Are Essential to Retention, Affordability. 
Women’s health can be a high cost driver for employers. Additionally, offering solutions to improve and support needs specific to women can also be an important factor to retention. But women’s health in general is not just one condition. Join us for this fireside chat in which Dr. Leslie Saltzman, Ovia Health’s chief medical officer, explains the different facets of women’s health (like menopause, fertility, and maternity care management), what areas generate the most ROI, and how employers can offer the deepest, and most all-encompassing benefits to support and delight their employees and medically supported dependents. 
Register now
. 
 
Nov. 9: How Tech Can Boost Engagement and Recognition.
 In a distributed workforce, how can employers promote both team cohesion and making individual employees feel "seen" by their managers and peers? What have business leaders learned in the past two years about which technologies and practices are motivational and informative, vs. fatiguing or counterproductive? 
Register now
. 
 
LIVE EVENTS
 
Join us in the real world! We hosted 14 single-day live conferences around the U.S. in 2022 and we have an even more ambitious slate underway in 2023. Our live events are also eligible for SHRM and HRCI credits.

VIRTUAL CONFERENCES
 
July 19: 
Innovation in Family Health: How Companies Can Take Personalized Approach
. 
Family health has taken on new dimensions over the past few years, as employers have recognized that in geographically distributed workplaces, employees face different circumstances when it comes to the availability and quality of fertility care, pediatric care, child care, education, and after-school programming. How can companies invested in family-friendly and caregiving benefits adapt to the variety of needs in their workforces? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
July 26: 
The New Keys to Employee Satisfaction, Recognition, and Retention
. 
The right combination of total rewards, career advancement, and corporate purpose has been a moving target in recent years as workers reconsider their priorities. How can companies accentuate the benefits of sticking with  their organizations, emphasizing factors including personal growth, fulfillment, and benefits tailored to their individual needs? Which tools can accurately measure employee satisfaction, and how can managers augment their effect? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Aug. 9: 
The Changing Profile of HR Leaders: How the Role Is Evolving and Growing
.
 In just the past two years, HR has risen to the C-suite level in influence and responsibility. How should HR leaders respond in terms of preparing for changing roles, managing their new duties, and charting their own career paths? What can HR leaders do to leverage their new prominence to make change happen across the whole organization? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Sept. 20: 
Building a Healthy Work Environment to Persevere Through Multiple Challenges
. 
Organizations offering health care and wellness benefits maintain a stronger sense of employee loyalty. Yet health and well-being among employees goes beyond acute or specific physical or mental health needs. How can companies create a culture that emphasizes health through everyday experience? What are the hidden opportunities to nurture this kind of culture? Rather than relying only on standard benefits to respond in times of unexpected distress, how can organizations address employee needs proactively? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Sept. 27: 
Giving Workers Direction About Skills and Career Development
. 
Many workers yearn to grow and advance in their careers, yet don’t have an understanding of how to develop their skills and experience for a role with more responsibility. Learning and development can help not only by showing the many possibilities, but also with vision to help employees find the learning and development path that will enable the most fulfilling growth according to their own interests. What can organizations do to deploy coaching in a way that helps not only with short-term goals but also the long arc of a worker’s career? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Oct. 11: 
How HR Technology Can Connect, Motivate, and Recognize the Hybrid Workforce
. 
Most workers have strongly embraced hybrid and remote work arrangements, having settled into sustainable routines that allow them to be productive. But camaraderie and a sense of belonging have proven elusive without meaningful face-to-face contact and team-building opportunities. How can organizations create new structures for in-person gatherings that maintain the comfort of remote or hybrid work, as well as new digital approaches that create the ties that bind? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Nov. 8: 
Casting a Wider Net: Fresh, Productive Approaches to Diversity Recruiting
. 
Many companies fall short of their diversity-hiring goals because they keep looking in the same places–and with the same techniques and expectations. What are the best ways for employers to break out of these patterns? How can they reconsider their job specifications to bring in more non-traditional candidates and prospects who could thrive with a modest amount of training and upskilling? What are the new and innovative ways to strengthen a diverse pipeline? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Dec. 13: 
The Arc of Change for People and Culture in 2024
. 
Recent history affirms that unpredictable events will buffet the workplace of 2024, yet the trajectory of trends in 2023 gives an indication of how organizations will need to be ready for changing expectations among workers and other stakeholders. What are the emerging patterns that leaders should watch in the realms of diversity and inclusion, talent acquisition, employee rewards, learning and development, social responsibility and sustainability? What new points of focus will arrive in the greater field of people and culture? 
Register here to attend
.

As an innovative Catholic, Vincentian university anchored in the global city of Chicago, DePaul supports the integral human development of its students. subject: ✉️ Last Chance to Register! Creating a Culture of Inclusion
body:
Reserve your seat for our July Learning with LCW webinar: Creating a Culture of Inclusion that Fosters High Performance.
 
Last chance to register! 
Learning with LCW Webinar
Reserve Your Seat
 
Wednesday, July 12 | 1pm CT
 
In the last three years, organizations have taken unprecedented steps to advance Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Belonging in their organizations. Have their efforts been successful? Creating impact that is both measurable and sustainable is both the most vital and most difficult aspect of DEIB work as well as of culture work more broadly.
 
LCW’s Sustainable Culture of Inclusion (SCI) Model serves as a framework for understanding organizational maturity. LCW believes that the cultural diversity inherent in all organizations is an asset that can be leveraged to build high performance, and that sustainable cultures of inclusion are the foundation for this success. Ultimately, the goal is to create a Sustainable Culture of Inclusion that produces both a positive working experience and equitable outcomes for employees.
In this session, we will:
Share the genesis & structure of the SCI Model
Discuss how we use the SCI model to diagnose organizations’ current state
Provide two case studies that demonstrate the model’s impact 
Facilitated by:
 
 
Sarah Nodarse
Principal Consultant, LCW
 
 
Vince Bongiovanni
Associate Consultant, LCW
 
 
 
 
 
Copyright © 2023 LCW, All rights reserved.
LCW, 4753 N Broadway, Floor 2, Chicago, Illinois 60640, USA

subject: Supreme Court Dismantles Affirmative Action in College Admissions, Jury Awards $25.6M to Ex-Starbucks Employee, Combatting Antisemitism, more
body:
SHRM reaffirmed its commitment to advocating for inclusive workplaces.
To view this email as a webpage, 
click here.
                                                            
 
 
 
 
SHRM’s Diversity, Equity & Inclusion
 News
 
July 10, 2023
 
 
 
 
You’re just getting started.
Access compliance alerts, tools and more.
JOIN NOW
 
 
 
INCLUSION 2023 Preconference Seminars 
 
Join us at SHRM INCLUSION 2023 in Savannah, Ga., a little early to extend your learning even further. We’ve developed three seminars* to best suit DE&I challenges you’re most likely to face in your role: 
Inclusive Workplace Culture
, 
Managing Change
 and 
Talent Acquisition: Creating Your Organization’s Strategy
. Take charge of your company culture and 
sign up today
. Don’t forget that the INCLUSION 2023 early-bird rate expires July 14! 
*Additional fee and registration is required. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Supreme Court Dismantles Affirmative Action in College Admissions
 
The U.S. Supreme Court has voted to end affirmative action in higher education, ruling that the practice violates the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment. Here’s what that may mean for employers. 
 
 
 
Fired for Being White? Jury Awards $25.6M to Ex-Starbucks Regional Director Who Alleged Race-Based Termination
A former regional director at Starbucks accused the coffee giant of firing her five years ago because she’s white. This month, a jury awarded her over $25 million.
 
Advertisement 
 
 
 
 
 
Let Language Learning Strengthen Your DEI Efforts 
Language learning promotes cultural understanding, facilitates effective communication, and empowers your workers. Plus, multilingual skills can help you create an open, inclusive team culture while strengthening communication and collaboration.
Learn more in our free eBook
 
 
 
 
 
White House Releases First-Ever Strategy to Combat Antisemitism
 
President Joe Biden recently introduced the federal government’s first-ever strategy to reduce antisemitism in the U.S. The plan includes over 100 calls-to-action for Congress, state and local governments, tech companies, and others to mitigate anti-Jewish hate, including in the workplace. 
 
 
 
Strategies for Reducing Record-Level Employee Stress
 
A recent Gallup poll revealed that 44 percent of employees said they experienced “a lot of stress” the previous day—matching the recorded high in 2021. Here are ways HR professionals can reduce stress and boost engagement among workers. 
 
Advertisement 
 
 
 
 
 
RESEARCH REPORT
Creating a High-Performance Culture: The Role of Company Culture in Driving Success
 
The results are in: Organizations that place a high priority on DEI initiatives were more than 2X more likely to see significant increases in revenue last year compared to others. Get insights from 300+ strategic leaders on how culture impacts performance in Arbinger’s latest research report.
DOWNLOAD REPORT
 
 
 
Job Seekers of Color Are Being ‘Ghosted’ at Alarmingly High Rates
 
Companies are cutting off communication with job applicants from underrepresented communities during the hiring process at significantly higher rates than they are with white candidates, new research reveals. 
 
 
 
AI Is More Likely to Replace Jobs Held by Women. Here’s Why.
 
Many employees fear that AI will eventually take their jobs, but a recent assessment conducted by analytics firm Revelio Labs found that automation is more likely to replace women than men in the job market. 
 
 
 
Why Are Employees of Color Leaving?
 
Kim Crowder, an Indiana-based workplace consultant, discussed at the SHRM Annual Conference & Expo 2023 (SHRM23) the factors influencing why employees of color are leaving the workplace in higher numbers to explore new career opportunities. 
 
Advertisement 
 
 
 
 
 
What Enterprise Companies Need To Know About Freelancers
 
Several common misconceptions about freelancers permeate enterprise companies, the most recurring and frequent being that freelancers are only used for simple projects and tasks. These misguided ideas result in overlooked critical talent, missed opportunities, and unrealized diversity.
Here are the realities that can dispel those misconceptions and myths.
 
 
 
Evolve Company Policies to Include Transgender Employees
 
Ben Greene, international speaker and CEO of BG Trans Talks, transitioned at age 15 and now, eight years later, continues to share his experiences. He spoke at SHRM23 about what companies can and should do to create more inclusive workplaces. 
 
 
PLAN AHEAD 
 
NOW
Michigan Bans Hairstyle Discrimination
Effective June 15, Michigan employers are prohibited from discriminating based on traits historically associated with race, such as hair texture and protective hairstyles.
NOW
NYC Restricts Use of AI in Hiring
New York City passed a first-of-its-kind law that will prohibit employers from using artificial intelligence and algorithm-based technologies for recruiting, hiring or promotion without those tools first being audited for bias.
NOW
Addressing Personal Hygiene
A colleague needs a shower. A co-worker should wear socks. A manager is asking if someone on your HR team might have a word with a particularly smelly associate. As temperatures rise, how to address the issue of body odor is a real concern in the workplace.
JUL
25
Deadline to Implement OFCCP’s New Self-Identification of Disability Form
The Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs (OFCCP) has revised its Voluntary Self-Identification of Disability Form (CC-305). The revised form updates the preferred language for disabilities and includes other examples of disabilities. Contractors must implement the new form by July 25.
JUL
31
I-9 Remote Verification Flexibility Ends
The COVID-19 flexibilities for Form I-9 review requirements will sunset on July 31. U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has announced that employers have until Aug. 30 to review I-9s in person for remote staff whose documents were examined remotely. ICE is recommending that employers plan ahead for the Aug. 30 compliance deadline so they are not left scrambling to complete the in-person inspections.
AUG
7
Colorado POWR Act Effective
Gov. Jared Polis has signed the Protecting Opportunities and Workers’ Rights (POWR) Act into law. The POWR Act expands the Colorado Anti-Discrimination Act by adding types of conduct that constitute harassment.
AUG
31
District of Columbia TWWFA Training Deadline
The District of Columbia’s Tipped Wage Workers Fairness Amendment (TWWFA) Act requires covered employers to provide anti-sexual harassment training to their employees, managers, owners and operators.
SEP
1
Texas Prohibits Hairstyle Discrimination
With the Sept. 1 effective date fast approaching, it’s time for Texas employers to prepare for a new law prohibiting discrimination based on hairstyles.
SEP
17
New York Statewide Pay Transparency Law
Covered employers in New York state will soon have pay transparency obligations related to job advertisements.
NOV
22
New York City Bans Height and Weight Discrimination
New York City Mayor Eric Adams has signed a law that will prohibit discrimination based on a person’s height or weight. The new law will apply to employment, housing and public accommodations.
 
SHRM WEBCASTS COMING SOON 
 
 
How Prioritizing Well-Being Drives Employee Engagement: GoTo’s Story
 
July 24, 2 p.m. ET / 11 a.m. PT 
Sponsor:
 
Workhuman
 
Workplaces that prioritize well-being see employees who are more engaged and productive. But what are the best ways to amplify well-being among today’s onsite, hybrid and remote employees? For insights, join us as we explore how GoTo implemented recognition to promote well-being and spark cultural transformation. You will learn tactical ways to create and maintain a positive, collaborative culture in a flexibility-first world, how GoTo is using team member recognition to fuel well-being and engagement, the latest research about the impact strategic recognition can have on employee burnout and turnover, and more. 
 
 
 
Age Diversity and Open Enrollment: How to Offer Inclusive Support to Your Multi-Generational Workforce
 
July 26, 4 p.m. ET / 1 p.m. PT 
Sponsor:
 
Jellyvision
 
Whether you’re considered a Baby Boomer, a member of Generation Z or somewhere in the middle, there are officially five (yes, five!) different generations in the workforce. This directly impacts your company culture, communication norms, career pathing and—you guessed it—benefits programs. In this informative program, we will discuss what each generation truly thinks about open enrollment, how employees want to receive benefits communication, what your employees want, how to make open enrollment more inclusive and much more. 
 
 
 
Addressing the Impact of Today’s Financial Stressors on Mental and Physical Health
 
July 27, 4 p.m. ET / 1 p.m. PT 
Sponsor:
 
Aetna
 
Today’s workforce continues to face many challenges ranging from layoff fears to hyperinflation, leading to employee stress and burnout. Employers need to understand the needs and gaps of their populations, identify resources and tools that can help employees bring their best selves to work, and take actions that can produce sustainable, positive change. This webinar will explore the challenges and provide examples of strategies, benefits and resources that help achieve desired outcomes for employers and employees alike. 
 
 
View the complete schedule of 
SHRM webcasts
. 
 
 
EXPRESS REQUEST 
 
 
SCOTUS Changes Standard for Religious Accommodation
 
The U.S. Supreme Court (SCOTUS) has changed the religious accommodation standard under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act. Under the new standard, the accommodation is an undue hardship only if the employer can prove it would result in substantial increased costs for the business. Visit SHRM’s 
SCOTUS Changes Standard for Religious Accommodation
 Express Request. 
 
 
HR JOBS 
 
Need to hire highly qualified HR candidates or looking to move your career forward?
SHRM HR Jobs can help you reach your goals by connecting top employers with premier HR professionals. Now more user-friendly and with new features, including the ability to filter candidates by SHRM credentials. 
Visit SHRM HR Jobs to learn more
.
HR Business Partner, Baseball Operations
 - Minnesota Twins - Minneapolis (Hybrid)
Human Resources Generalist
 - Legal Aid Society of Greater Cincinnati - Cincinnati (Onsite)
Bilingual Benefits Coordinator
 - Legend Management Group - McLean, Va. (Onsite)
 
 
USEFUL LINKS 
 
SHRM Foundation’s Getting Talent Back to Work: Take the first step toward learning how to reduce barriers for people with criminal records in your workplace.
Have global HR responsibilities? SHRM’s Knowledge Center has compiled employment law resources for over 40 countries.
SHRM’s Employee Handbook Builder simplifies the process of ensuring that your staff has an updated policy guide to all things work.
 
 
FEATURED WHITE PAPERS
 
 
 
BambooHR vs. Paychex Flex: Features, Ratings and Reviews
 
 
OFFERED BY:  
Software Advice 
 
BambooHR or Paychex Flex: Which is a better fit for your business? To help you answer that, we analyzed reviews from actual users who scored these products on value, ease of use and more—so you have the info you need to choose your ideal software. Download this report to reveal the results of our study. 
 
READ MORE
 
 
Paylocity vs. ADP Workforce Now: Ratings Compared
 
 
OFFERED BY: 
Software Advice 
 
Which of these popular software vendors is a better fit for your business? The differences between them could mean the success or failure of the tool for your business. To learn more, download this resource to hear honest feedback from other software users. 
 
READ MORE
 
 
Access more content and insights from 
SHRM’s White Paper Library
. 
 
 
 
 
Connect with us on social!
 
  
  
  
  
 
1800 Duke Street, Alexandria, Virginia 22314 USA 
Contact Us
 |

subject: Training Industry Weekly Recap 📅 July 9, 2023
body:
New infographic, internal consulting workshop and more. 
View this email in your browser
THE BUSINESS OF LEARNING™
Whether they realize it or not, training managers embody a crucial element of organizational leadership, with their efforts directly contributing to employees’ ability to keep up with social and technological change.
To equip you with the tools you need to support learners through the increasing pace of change, 
Training Industry Magazine’s Summer issue
 features articles on how you can give better feedback, help to close the digital skills gap and foster a performance-first mindset. We’re also excited to highlight our 
State of the Industry report
 on the leadership training market, an 
infographic
 on improving the employee experience and more.
As always, we love hearing from you; reach out to 
editor@trainingindustry.com
 with any article ideas, questions or suggestions. Have a great week!
Mike Allen, CPTM
Editor
[Infographic] 3 Ways Training Can Improve the Employee Experience
Study after study indicates employees who don’t have opportunities to learn and grow in their organization are more likely to be disengaged and disconnected. Our 
latest infographic
 offers three ways to enhance the employee experience through training. Download now to learn how training can boost engagement and retention by offering opportunities for growth, collaboration and connection.
Get the Infographic
 
Beyond Implementation: Internal Consulting Workshop
The most effective training professionals are not only skilled at training design and delivery, but also act as strong internal consultants who partner with business stakeholders to build and implement solutions that drive business results. Attend the next 
internal consulting master class
 on July 28 to learn more about the consulting process and the basics of contracting, as well as strategies for gaining executive buy-in.
Learn More
 
[State of the Industry Report] The Leadership Training Market
Organizations continue to see the value in internal mobility for retaining top talent and, as a result, the leadership training market remains a fast-growing sector. Our 
annual report
 uses data and market insights to cover changes in leadership development over time, the size of the current market, universal and emerging topics, and trends based on our Top 20 Leadership Training Companies List. These insights will help you better understand the leadership training market and the evolution into virtual leadership development.
Get the Report
 
Training Industry Magazine’s Summer Issue
The Summer 2023 issue of Training Industry Magazine is out now! It's up to L&D to prepare organizations for the increasing pace of change; but first, we need to align our goals and how to measure them. 
This edition
 includes articles on developing a performance-first mindset, giving better feedback, bridging the digital skills gap, designing employee competency rubrics and more. Check it out now!

Your free guide to diagnosing DEI issues
 
It's tough when you launch DEI initiatives and the reality doesn't match the strategy. 
It’s frustrating. Disappointing. And it can take a heavy toll on you, your team, and the employees whose working lives you’re trying to improve.  
 
We see it time and again in the organisations we work with. So much so, that we wanted to

dentify key reasons behind struggling DEI initiatives.

HBR STORE
 
 
 
 
 
Transform challenges into opportunities 
 
Do you and your team need to make more creative, flexible and impactful decisions? Move from an "either/or" mindset to a “both/and” approach. 
 
 
 
 
 
LEARN TO:
•
Effectively tackle strategic challenges and competing demands
•
Uncover less obvious and better solutions
•
Better cope with stressful decisions and conflicting priorities
•
Avoid the same issues resurfacing again and again
•
Apply these approaches to strategy, leadership and even personal dilemmas
•
And much more
 
LEARN MORE
 
 
 
 
 
 
THE EBOOK
Our brains love to make "either/or" choices, which are limiting and can even be detrimental. In this book grounded in 20+ years of research, you’ll discover how to transform tensions into opportunities for innovation and personal growth.

subject: How the Shift to Remote Work Made Learning Better
body:
In many cases, it actually works better than in-person.
View this email  in your browser
How the Shift to Remote Work Made Learning Better
The pandemic accelerated digital transformation by a factor of 40. Now, reflecting on their experiences digitizing in-person learning for hybrid and remote workforces, corporate learning and development (L&D) leaders report that online learning not only works — in many cases, it actually works better than in-person. 
Through independent research commissioned by NovoEd, L&D leaders from 150 large corporate enterprises weighed in on these experiences. 
“How The Shift to Remote Work Made Learning Better,”
 
includes insights on how corporate leaders are applying lessons learned to transform L&D for the new reality.
Download the research report and learn:
As L&D leaders reflect on the past few years, how are they feeling about remote learning?
What has gone better than expected, and what challenges did they encounter?
Which types of training transitioned to an online format more easily?
How are leaders accelerating training programs that increase organizational resiliency?
Download the Report
